The  Punjab  is  the  most  populous  province  of  Pakistan  and  has  the 
largest provincial economic base in the country, accounting for 56% of 
the  total  population  and  over  50%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP). 
The  province  has  achieved  robust  economic  growth  and  significant 
poverty reduction, matching its structural reforms, since early 2000. Yet 
reforms in many areas are only partial, poverty is still high at over 20%, 
and  social  indicators  lag  behind  those  in  comparable  low-income 
countries.   
 
The  government  of  Punjab  (GoPb)  has  laid  down  an  ambitious  Vision 
2020  aimed  at  doubling  per  capita  income  over  the  next  decade.  This 
will  require  sustained  broad-based  economic  growth,  which  in  turn 
demands  large  efficiency  improvements  in  both  the  private  and  the 
public  sectors,  accompanied  by  better  public  resource  management. 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)–supported  Punjab 
Through 
Resource  Management  Program 
implemented  during 
November  2003–August  2007,  the  GoPb  has  introduced  wide-ranging 
reforms  in  public  resource  management.  It  has  enhanced  revenues, 
rationalized  expenditures,  improved  planning  and  budgeting,  and 
developed the private sector and the civil service. In parallel, the GoPb

 has  also  implemented  reforms  in  service  delivery,  through  the  ADB-
supported Punjab Devolved Social Services Program (PDSSP), and in 
the judiciary, through the Access to Justice Program (AJP). 
 
Having  laid  down  a  broad  foundation  for  reforms  through  these  three 
major ADB interventions, and support from other development partners 
in  the  governance,  education,  and  infrastructure  sectors,  the  GoPb 
launched 
fourth  Punjab 
Development  Forum  in  April  2007.  These  reforms  are  centered  on 
creating  an  effective  public  sector  and  fostering  a  dynamic  private 
sector to achieve the Vision 2020 goals.  
 
The key pillars of the second-generation reforms are the following: 
  
(i) 

efficient public financial management, to increase the fiscal space 
for higher pro-poor spending;

service;  

(iv)  broad  measures  supporting  private  sector  development,  for

Building  on  the  PRMP  and  other  programs,  PGEIP  will  support  the 
GoPb  in  realizing  the  long-term  goals  expressed  in  Vision  2020, 
through  which  the  government  has  committed  itself  to  significantly 
improving the standard of living of the people of Punjab, especially the 
poor and vulnerable. The PGEIP will improve the overall functioning of 
the  provincial,  district,  and  municipal  governments  and  the  quality  of 
public services. The improvements will take the following forms:  
 
(i) 
(ii) 

greater performance-oriented planning and budgeting;  
a  more  efficient  civil  service,  with  adequate  incentives  and 
merit-based appointment and career progression;  

(iii)  a funded and well-managed pension system, which increases the 
confidence  of  civil  servants  and  the  public,  and  generates  fiscal 
space for high-priority investments in the social sectors; and  
(iv)  greater  private  sector  contribution  to  growth  and  facilitation  of 

public-private partnerships.

As  reforms  in  these  areas  are  complex  and  take  time  to  filter  through 
the  bureaucracy,  PGEIP  will  be  processed  as  a  program  cluster 
comprising  three  single-tranche  SPs.  This  modality  provides  adequate 
flexibility  to  meet  emerging  reform  needs  and  use  program  conditions 
genuinely  for  policy  reform,  rather  than  as  rigid  prescriptions.  ADB’s 
Management  and  Board  will  also  have  greater 
in 
recommending measures for future operations within a cluster, in a way 
that  is  not  possible  in  traditional  multiple-tranche  operations.  Separate 
reports and recommendations of the President (RRPs) will be prepared 
for each subprogram. The policy matrix developed thus far for SP1 has 
indicative  actions  for  SP2  and  SP3.  In  addition,  detailed  action  plans 
will be developed in combination with policy matrices to guide reforms. 
 
In order to ensure that all the six pillars of the Vision 2020 are in place, 
the  GoPb  has  also  sought  ADB’s  support  for  accelerating  the 
attainment  of  the  MDGs  and  implementation  of  provincial-level  judicial 
reforms,  in  addition  to  the  government  efficiency  improvements  under 
PGEIP.  
 
In  line  with this  request,  ADB  will  also  prepare  two  additional  program 
clusters, namely the PMDGP and PAJP, in an integrated manner along 
with  PGEIP  over  2007–2011.  The  integrated  approach  and  the 
preliminary details of the PMDGP and PAJP are presented in Appendix 
3  of  this  RRP.  The  integrated  approach  will  improve  program 
coordination,  reduce  duplication,  minimize  inconsistency  in  policy 
advice and measures, and focus resources for desired outcomes. 
 
The  reforms  under  the  three  program  clusters  will  accelerate  and 
sustain economic growth, improve the delivery of public services, create 
more employment opportunities, and reduce poverty. 
 
GoPb has expressed a strong commitment to accelerating the funding 
of  its  civil  service  pension  system,  so  that  the  annual  pension 
obligations  can  be  made  off-budget  to  the  extent  possible  and  the 
conserved  resources  utilized  for  essential  social  and  infrastructure 
investments.  To  translate  this  commitment  to  action,  GoPb  needs 
significant resources, for which it has requested financing support over 
the  next  5  years  through  the  PGEIP,  PMDGP,  and  PAJP  clusters.  In 
parallel,  the  three  clusters  will  also  help  leverage  reforms  in  the 
respective areas. 
 
For  the  PGEIP  cluster,  three  well-sequenced  single-tranche  loans  are 
proposed.  The  PMDGP  and  PAJP  clusters  will  be  processed  and 
presented for Board consideration separately over the course of 2008–
2011.  
  
For  SP1  of  PGEIP,  a  loan  of  $250  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources  (OCR)  will  be  provided  under  ADB’s  London  interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)–based lending facility. The loan will have a term of 
15  years  including  a  grace  period  of  3  years,  an  interest  rate  to  be

determined according to ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility, and other

The  Government  of  Pakistan  will  relend  the  local  currency  generated 
from  the  proceeds  of  the  loan  to  the  GoPb,  on  the  same  terms  and 
conditions  as  those  extended  by  ADB  to  the  Government.  The  GoPb 
will assume the foreign exchange risk and interest rate risk. 
  
SP2  and  SP3  of  the  PGEIP  are  also  envisaged  to  involve  loans  of 
$250 million each, to be reconfirmed by the GoPb and the Government 
of Pakistan in 2008–2009 (for SP2) and 2010–2011 (for SP3).   
 
The local currency counterpart funds generated from the OCR loan will 
be  used  to  capitalize  the  Pension  Fund  and  the  General  Provident 
Fund,  finance  the  costs  of  structural  adjustments,  and  increase  social 
expenditure. 
 
SP1  of  the  PGEIP  covers  reform  measures  implemented  from  June 
2006  to  October  2007.  The  proceeds  of  the  $250  million  loan  for  the 
subprogram,  withdrawable  in  a  single  tranche,  will  be  available  after 
loan  effectiveness,  upon  satisfactory  attainment  of  all  agreed  policy 
actions  under  SP1.  The  RRP  for  the  SP2  loan  will  be  submitted  for 
Board  consideration  about  18–20 months  after  the  SP1  loan  becomes 
effective,  subject  to  the  GoPb’s  readiness  to  continue  with  its  reform 
agenda.  Similarly,  the  RRP  for  the  SP3  will  be  submitted  for  Board 
consideration  about  18–20  months  after  SP2  loan  becomes  effective, 
subject  to  the  government’s  readiness  to  continue  with  the  reform 
agenda. The period of the PGEIP cluster will be from October 2007 to 
late 2010 or early 2011, and is expected to close on 30 June 2011.  
 
For the PGEIP, the Planning and Development Department (P&DD) of 
GoPb will be the Executing Agency (EA).  
 
A high-level steering committee chaired by the chief secretary of Punjab 
and  comprising  as  members,  the  Planning  and  Development  (P&D) 
chairman,  additional 
secretary  Services  and  General 
Administration  Department  (S&GAD),  finance  secretary,  secretaries  of 
Implementing Agencies (IAs), and at least three representatives of civil 
society and the private sector, will guide PGEIP implementation. 
 
The  principal  IAs  for  the  PGEIP  will  be  the  FD  and  P&DD  for  public 
financial  management;  FD  for  pension  reforms;  the  Public  Policy  and 
Change  Management  Wing  (PPCMW)  of  S&GAD,  and  Management

Program Benefits 
and Beneficiaries 

 
An  executive  committee  under  the  P&D  chairman  and  comprising 
members from FD and S&GAD, will ensure the efficient implementation 
of  the  PGEIP.  A  program  management  unit  (PMU),  established  for 
PRMP  and  in  place  since  2003,  will  continue  to  be  the  secretariat  for 
the two committees. 
 
The  loan  proceeds  will  finance  the  foreign  exchange  costs  (excluding 
local duties and taxes) of items produced in and procured from ADB’s 
member countries, excluding ineligible items and imports financed from 
other bilateral and multilateral sources. ADB will have the right to audit 
the use of the loan proceeds and verify the accuracy of the Borrower’s 
certification.  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  to  the  Borrower 
according  to  ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and 
Related Requirements for Program Loans.  
 
The  PGEIP  will  significantly  benefit  the  people  of  the  Punjab  through 
the following:  
 
(i)  Better  management  of  public 

resources  and  more 
performance-oriented  planning  and  budgeting.  Fiscal 
discipline  will  be  effectively  enforced,  resource 
flows  and 
performance  outcomes  will  be  better  linked,  there  will  be  greater 
coherence 
development 
expenditures,  and  public  service  delivery  will  improve,  with  direct 
benefit to the poor.

between 

policy

(ii)  A financially sustainable and adequate pension system. There 
will  be  greater  retirement  income  security  for  civil  servants,  and 
fiscal space will be created for pro-poor expenditures. Longer-term 
benefits  include  the  promotion  of  private  saving  and  asset 
accumulation,  which  will  contribute  to  economic  growth,  besides 
financial sector development.  

(iii)  An  efficient  and  effective  civil  service.  Improved  human 
resource  management  in  the  civil  service  will  increase  value  for 
money for the province. The efficiency gains will produce benefits 
in  service  delivery  and  private  sector  development.  A  more 
responsive  civil  service  will  also  lead  to  more  equitable  public 
expenditures, with benefit to the poor.  

(iv)  Greater  private  sector  participation.  A  coherent  private  sector 
development  strategy  and  an  improved  regulatory  framework  will 
help  reduce  the  cost  of  doing  business,  and  result  in  greater 
efficiency, investments, growth, and poverty reduction. Likewise, a 
robust public-private partnership will mobilize resources for better 
service delivery. 

 
Overall,  PGEIP  will  result  in  better  public  services  and  broad-based 
economic  growth.  Key  derivative  benefits 
include  employment 
generation and poverty reduction.      

 
Assumption, Risks, 
and Safeguards 

The  realization  of  the  benefits  of  the  PGEIP  depends  on  a  number  of 
assumptions  and  is  subject  to  various  risks.  Mitigating  measures  have 

 

 vi 

 

 

 
Technical 
Assistance Loan 
 
 

 

risks.  The  PGEIP 

therefore been integrated into the design of the Program. 
 
Political risks. Pakistan is in an election year and any political changes 
could  have  major  administrative  consequences.  But  the  risk  of 
reversing  the  direction of  reforms  is  quite  low  in  the  Punjab,  given  the 
broad consensus on reforms among the key stakeholders. The flexibility 
built  into  the  single-tranche  operations  also  addresses  any  uncertainty 
in  this  regard,  as  reform  actions  can  be  adjusted  to  suit  the  emerging 
environment  as  long  as  the  overall  development  needs  are  met  in  an 
efficient manner without significant distortions.  
 
Governance  risks.  Reforms  could  be  undermined  or  delayed  by 
vested interests threatened by greater transparency and accountability. 
But strong ownership and support for the PGEIP at the highest political 
and bureaucratic levels, coupled with gradually improving incentives for 
better  performance,  will  help  mitigate  this  risk.  Further,  the  proposed 
program design has benefited from broad stakeholder consultation and 
participation.  
 
Implementation 
implementation  demands 
considerable institutional capacity. Insufficient capacity within the GoPb 
to manage the envisaged reforms could impede implementation. Earlier 
ADB  support  has  helped  the  PMU  and  the  government  departments 
overcome capacity limitations. In addition, the attached TA loan and TA 
grants will provide capacity building to ensure reform sustainability.  
 
External 
geopolitical 
uncertainties,  the  external  environment  has  been  largely  favorable  to 
Pakistan  over  the  past  few  years.  The  country’s  macroeconomic 
indicators in the past 5 years have been strong. But the widening trade 
imbalance and current account deficit, insecurity in the region, and the 
cost  of  earthquake  reconstruction  heighten  the  macroeconomic  risks. 
While  some  of  the  risks  are  beyond  the  control  of  the  Government  of 
Pakistan  and  the  GoPb,  prudent  economic  management  can  lessen 
macroeconomic vulnerability.  
 
A  TA  loan  of  $8.8  million  equivalent  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources will be provided to support public resource management and 
related  reforms  in  the  Punjab.  The  loan  will  have  a  term  of  32  years 
including  a  grace  period  of  8 years,  an  interest  rate  of  1%  per  year 
during the grace period and 1.5% per year thereafter, and other terms 
and conditions set forth in the TA loan and TA program agreements. 
 
The TA loan is intended to support the implementation of reforms called 
for  under  the  PGEIP.  Specifically,  the  TA  will  support  policy  advice, 
diagnostic  studies,  stakeholder  consultations,  and  capacity  building  to 
achieve  (i)  greater  performance  orientation  in  planning  and  budgeting, 
(ii)  a  financially  stable  and  adequate  pension  system  with  improved 
benefits and wider coverage, (iii) an efficient and effective civil service, 
and  (iv)  a  dynamic  private  sector.  The  TA  loan  will  have  five 
components:  (i) fiscal  and  financial  management,  (ii)  pension  reform, 

and  macroeconomic

(iii) civil service reform, (iv) private sector development, and (v) reform 
monitoring and evaluation.  
 
P&DD will be the EA for the TA loan and various IAs will be responsible 
for their respective components. The main IAs will be FD, P&DD, DOH, 
and DI&P for component 1; FD for component  2; S&GAD and MPDD 
for  component  3;  the  Departments  of  Commerce  and  Investment, 
Industries,  and  Labor  and  Human  Resource  for  component  4;  and 
P&DD for component 5.  
 
Consultants will be recruited according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  A  total  of  140 
person-months  of  international  and  156  person-months  of  national 
consultants will be required. 
 
An  advisory  TA  for  $950,000  equivalent  will  support  the  effective 
implementation  of  the  PGEIP  by  improving  the  interface  between  line 
agencies in the GoPb. In parallel, it will also help enhance the fiduciary 
governance of the Punjab civil service pension system, and initiate civil 
service  reforms  as  TA  loan  mobilization  takes  place  over  the  next  6 
months.  A  program  preparatory  TA  for  $900,000  equivalent  will  help 
prepare the proposed PMDGP and PAJP outlined in Appendix 3 of this 
RRP.

program  cluster  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  the  Punjab  Government  Efficiency 
Improvement  Program  (PGEIP)  comprising  three  subprograms;  (ii)  a  proposed  loan  for 
Subprogram  1  of  the  PGEIP;1 and  (iii)  a  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  loan  for  capacity 
building  for  PGEIP.  The  report  also  describes  proposed  TA  for  effective  implementation  of 
PGEIP  and  for  preparation  of  the  Punjab  Millennium  Development  Goals  Program  (PMDGP) 
and  the  Punjab  Access  to  Justice  Program  (PAJP),  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed 
PGEIP  cluster  and  loans,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  will 
approve the two TAs. 

    

II. 

MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

A. 

Macroeconomic Performance 

2. 
The Punjab is the largest provincial economy of Pakistan, accounting for over 50% of the 
country’s  gross  domestic  product  (GDP).  It  is  also  the  most  populous  province,  with  about 
87 million  inhabitants,  or  56%  of  the  country’s  population.  The  economic  performance  of  the 
Punjab thus plays a critical role in the overall economic strength of Pakistan. At the same time, 
national policies have a significant impact on the economic conditions in the Punjab.  
 
3. 
The economy of Pakistan as a whole has experienced a dramatic turnaround since 2001, 
behind sustained structural reforms. Real GDP grew by an average of 7% over the past 3 years, 
a  vast  improvement  over  the  1.8%  rate  in  2001.  Growth  has  been  supported  by  strong 
consumption  and  investment,  spurred  in  turn  by  increased  workers’  remittances,  among  other 
things.  Reflecting  its  continued  commitment  to  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction,  the 
Government  of  Pakistan  has  significantly  increased  development  spending,  particularly  in 
pro-poor sectors, from 4.8% of GDP in fiscal year (FY) 2005 to 5.6% in FY2006. Prudent debt 
management coupled with strong GDP growth, has led to a significant drop in the ratio of public 
debt to GDP, from 81.4% in FY2002 to 56.1% in FY2006, and in the ratio of external public debt 
to GDP, from 41.0% to 26.2% over the same period.   
 
4. 
The economy of the Punjab has also staged a major turnaround, from a contraction of 
0.9% in FY2001 to strong growth of 7.1% in FY2006. On the back of such performance, about 
3.5 million new jobs have been created each year since 2004, the poverty head-count ratio has 
declined by about 11% since 2002, and key social indicators such as the school enrollment rate 
have  significantly  improved.  Better  fiscal  management  has  also  created  “fiscal  space.”  As  a 
result  of  strong  growth  and  greater  fiscal  space,  development  expenditures  increased 
substantially  in  2003–2007  from  0.9%  of  gross  provincial  product  to  2.2%,  while  recurrent 
expenditures dropped from 4.5% to 4% over the same period. This general trend is expected to 
continue in the near future,2 with development expenditures growing by 21% yearly, nearly twice 
as fast as recurrent expenditures, which are expected to grow by 11%.3

 B. 

Punjab’s Development Vision, Strategy, and Medium-Term Development Plan  

5. 
Despite  strong  economic  performance,  the  province  is  confronted  by  many  challenges 
that  face  the  country  as  a  whole,  including  improving  the  investment  climate,  making  exports 
more  competitive,  sustaining  economic  growth,  accelerating  social  development,  and  reducing 
poverty.  Poverty  remains  high  in  the  Punjab  and  social  indicators  lag  behind  those  in 
comparable  low-income  countries.  Furthermore,  with  the  labor  force  growing  at  about  3%  per 
year, the creation of more jobs is a major challenge.  
 
6. 
Fully  aware  of  the  development  challenges,  the  government  of  the  Punjab  (GoPb) 
recognized  early  on  that  an  efficient  public  sector  is  the  key  to  economic  and  social 
transformation  in  the  Punjab.  It  designed  and  initiated  the  Punjab  Resource  Management 
Program  (PRMP)  with  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  support  in  2002,  focusing  on  public 
financial  management  and  private  sector  development,  among  others.  Subsequently,  in  June 
2004  GoPb  launched  the  Punjab  Vision  2020,  setting  out  its  main  development  objectives  for 
the next 15 years. Vision 2020 envisages a doubling of per capita income to about $2,000 within 
that  period.  The  major  goal  of  the  Vision  2020  is  a  dynamic  economy  with  an  efficient  public 
sector and a productive private sector. It identifies six pillars of reforms:

7. 
GoPb  has  been  a  pioneer  in  public  sector  reforms  in  Pakistan.  It  has  made  significant 
commitments  and  initiated  key  reforms  in  all  of  the  above  areas.  Yet,  given  the  complexity  of 
change,  the  Punjab  needs  major  improvements  on  three  fronts:  (i)  enhancing  public  sector 
efficiency;  (ii)  increasing  access  to,  as  well  as  the  quality,  of  public  services,  most  critically  in 
education,  health  and  water  and  sanitation  sectors;  and  (iii)  accelerating  private  sector 
participation in the provision of services. Appendix 2 presents a detailed analysis of the principal 
weaknesses  in  these  areas.  The  province  needs  a  large  infusion  of  public  and  private 
investments  to  keep  pace  with  the  growth  requirements  of  its  economy.  With  the  population 
growing  at  2.64%  per  year,  Punjab  will  double  its  size  to  over  150  million  people  by  2026.  At 
present, about 70% of the population is considered as vulnerable (children, women and elderly). 
Significant  urban-rural  differentials  exist  in  the  availability  and  quality  of  public  services.  Basic 
health indicators in the province are poor. Over 40% of villages have no drainage, and only 3% 
of villages have easy access to proper government hospitals. While infant mortality has declined 
from  above  120  in  1997  to  below  75  now,  Punjab  is  still  a  long  way  away  from  its  2015 
Millennium  Development  Goal  (MDG)  target  of  40  per  1,000  live  births.  Likewise,  maternal 
mortality remains high at 300 (as of 2004) against a 2015 target of 140 per 100,000 live births. 
With  the  growing  urban  congestion  and  rural-urban  inequalities,  Punjab  also  needs  to  invest 
massively  in  transport,  water  supply  and  sanitation  and  other  infrastructure.  These  cannot  be 
met  by  the  public  sector  alone.  And,  more  importantly,  the  economy  needs  to  grow  at  a 
sustained 7-8% per year to generate adequate jobs to those entering the labor force.

10. 
The  GoPb  launched  the  Punjab  Development  Forum  (PDF)  in  2003  to  engage  civil

The PRMP has provided strong support to the PDF, and ADB has been an active participant in

III. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, ISSUES, AND OPPORTUNITIES6 

A. 

Issues and Opportunities with Reference to the Proposed PGEIP    

1. 

Need for More Performance-Oriented Budgeting  

12. 
Background. The experience of countries worldwide has shown that the medium-term 
expenditure  framework  (MTEF),  which  combines  a  top-down  approach  to  fiscal  planning  with 
bottom-up  estimates  of  the  current  and  medium-term  costs  of  sector  programs,  can  be  a 
valuable  tool  in  public  expenditure  management.  The  GoPb  has  made  considerable  progress 
toward  adopting  a  medium-term  approach  to  fiscal  planning.  The  PRMP  supported  the 
introduction  of  a  medium-term  budget  framework  (MTBF)  and  a  medium-term  development 
framework  (MTDF),  with  3-year  projections  of  the  aggregate  resources  for  the  recurrent  and 
development budgets, respectively. The Finance Department (FD) prepares the MTBF, and the 
Planning and Development Department (P&DD), the MTDF. But despite the progress made in 
recent years, fiscal and public financial management in Punjab is still hampered by a number of 
issues.7 
 
13.  Weak  Budget  Preparation  and  Execution,  and  Poor  Performance  Orientation. 
Budgeting in Punjab is a dual system: the FD prepares and manages the recurrent budget, and 
P&DD,  the  development  budget.  Line  departments  submit  their  recurrent  and  development 
expenditure  estimates  to  FD  and  P&DD,  respectively,  which  in  turn  makes  the  final  budget 
allocations. Recurrent budget estimates are based on historical trends, with yearly increments to 
cover  additional  costs.  The  development  budget  consists  of  ongoing  programs  and  new 
programs  that  will  start  in  the  new  fiscal  year.  A  major  shortcoming  of  this  incremental  and 
input-oriented approach is that budget allocations hardly reflect sectoral service delivery goals 
and  priorities.  For  lack  of  a  robust  mechanism  for  preparing  budget  estimates,  the  line 
departments must often ask the FD for supplementary grants during the fiscal year to augment 
their  initial  budgetary  allocations. 8 There  is  no  periodic  review  of  recurrent  expenditures  to

identify  opportunities  to  reallocate  resources  and  increase  the  efficiency  of  public  spending.9 
Midyear monitoring of budget execution is limited to assessing whether the expenditures of line 
departments  conform  to  the  budgeted  amounts.  Budget  performance  is  not  monitored,  and 
irregularities  are  not  corrected.  Dual  budgeting  impedes  the  comprehensive  analysis  of 
government operations and the evaluation of their outcomes and results. As brought out in the 
public  expenditure  and  financial  accountability  (PEFA)  assessment  of  the  audit  function  (see 
footnote  7),  accountability  in  the  use  of  public  resources  needs  strengthening.  The  quality  of 
internal  audit  was  rated  substandard  (“C”),  as  audit  reports  are  not  prepared  regularly  and 
internal audit recommendations are not followed up. The external audit function was also rated 
substandard  (“D”)  because  audit  reports  are  submitted  late  and  there  is  little  response  to  or 
follow-up of audit observations by the entities concerned. Finally, though legislative scrutiny of 
external audit reports is quite extensive and detailed, the examination of these reports is often 
substantially delayed (D).  

 

14. 
Low  Value  for  Money  in  Public  Service  Delivery.  Since  devolution,  the  district 
governments  have  been  primarily  responsible  for  education  and  health  care,  and  the  tehsil 
municipal  administration  (TMAs) 10   and  the  union  councils,  for  water  supply  and  sanitation. 
Improved service delivery is a major tenet of devolution.  
 
15. 
However,  service  devolution  has  been  difficult  to  implement  effectively.  A  primary 
constraint is  the  mismatch  between  functional  responsibilities  and  financial  resources.  Despite 
their increased responsibilities, local governments derive their revenues chiefly from taxes with 
a  narrow  base  and  buoyancy, 11  and  therefore  depend  on  transfers  from  the  federal  and 
provincial governments. Most local governments are also unable to provide adequate services 
because  of  weak  human  capital,  infrastructure,  and  facilities,  and  the  lack  of  incentives  to 
provide good services.  
 
16. 
Limited  Integration  between  Budgeting  and  Planning.  The  MTBF  and  the  MTDF 
need to be combined into a single MTEF, which integrates the top-down resource envelope with 
the  bottom-up  sector  programs  in  the  annual  budget  process.  However,  the  MTBF  and  the 
MTDF as currently implemented in the Punjab represent only the top-down dimension, as they 
are  estimated  entirely  by  central  departments.  Line  departments  in  fact  have  only  limited 
involvement  in  determining  the  final  allocation  of  resources  and  expenditure  ceilings.  The 
annual budget and the MTBF differ in format, making it difficult to reconcile the two documents, 
though the annual budget should be identical to the first year of the MTBF. Budget projections 
are  not  driven  by  official  costing  guidelines  or  performance  targets,  and  are  not  based  on  the 
budget ceilings defined for individual departments. In the case of the recurrent budget, the FD 
gives  an  informal  indication  of  the  likely  allowable  increase,  while  in  the  case  of  the 
development  budget,  much  of  the  annual  development  program  is  already  known,  as  this 
comprises expenditure on ongoing projects and on projects that will start in the new budget year 
and that have already been approved and prioritized. As a result, there is no robust link between

17.  Weak  Tax  Administration. Tax administration capacity is one of the weakest areas in 
the GoPb’s public financial management, and the government for this reason cannot fully exploit 
its  revenue-generation  capacity.12 The  GoPb  began  the  reform  of  major  taxes,  including  the 
stamp duty, the agriculture income tax, and the urban immovable property tax, under the PRMP, 
to  boost  provincial  revenue,  but  was  constrained  by  weaknesses  in  tax  administration.  At 
present, tax administration in the province is the responsibility of two separate departments: the 
Board of Revenue and the Excise and Taxation Department. The Board of Revenue administers 
stamp  duties  and  the  agriculture  income  tax,  while  the  Excise  and  Taxation  Department 
administers  the  rest  of  the  taxes.  This  dual  authority  results  in  inefficiencies  and  revenue 
leakages. Poor record-keeping also impairs proper assessment of the effective tax liability. The 
weak capacity of tax administrators further compounds the poor performance of the tax system.  
 

2. 

Need for a Stronger Civil Service Pension System 

18. 
Background.  With  about  one  million  civil  servants  and  about  388,000  pensioners,  the 
government is the largest employer in the Punjab. The pension system has two main pillars: the 
Punjab  Pension  System  (PPS)  and  the  General  Provident  Fund  (GPF).  Membership  in  both 
schemes is mandatory. The pension system faces the following key challenges.  
 
19.  Weak Fiscal and Financial Sustainability. The PPS is a defined benefit system that is 
noncontributory  and  unfunded,  and  is  financed  from  the  annual  budget  of  the  provincial 
government.  The  GPF  is  also  an  unfunded  defined  contribution  scheme.  Civil  servants’ 
contributions to the GPF are not invested to meet future liabilities, which are financed through 
the  general  budget.  Liabilities  arising  from  pension  and  GPF  obligations  make  up  the  largest 
category  of  the  province’s  implicit  liabilities.  Preliminary  actuarial  estimates  indicate  that  the 
present discounted value of the GoPb’s pension liability could be as high as PRs400 billion. The 
outstanding  GPF  balance,  including  contributions  and  interest  credited,  is  reported  at  PRs15 
billion.  Pension  and  GPF  outlays  have  escalated  in  recent  years,  and  in  2006  amounted  to 
PRs12.6  billion  and  PRs4.3  billion,  respectively,  significantly  larger  than  the  government’s 
spending on public health (PRs5.5 billion) and agriculture (PRs2.5 billion). 
 
20. 
The  GoPb  recognizes  that  its  pension  obligations  have  important  implications  for  the 
finances  of  the  province,  and  that  pension  expenditures,  if  unchecked,  could  crowd  out 
investment in the infrastructure and social sectors.     
 
21. 
Gaps  in  Pension  Record-Keeping,  Administration,  and  Payment.  In  conducting  its 
payroll functions, the Office of the Accountant General, Punjab (AGP) records the employment 
history  of  civil  servants.  At  retirement,  the  worker  submits  an  application  to  the  office,  which 
calculates  the  worker’s  benefits.  Pension  payments  are  made  monthly  through  a  designated 
payment  agent  at  a  branch  of  the  National  Bank  of  Pakistan  (NBP).  The  balance  on  the  GPF 
account is taken as a lump sum at retirement. 
 
22. 
Record-keeping  and  benefit  calculations  are  largely  manual  and  paper-based.  The 
absence of a robust record-keeping and information management system, combined with weak 
financial analysis and accounting capacity, has resulted in inaccuracies in pension entitlement 

                                                 
12 The recent PEFA assessment rated tax administration capacity substandard (“C+”) with respect to transparency of 
taxpayer obligations and liabilities, and effectiveness of measures for taxpayer registration and tax assessment.  

  

 

7

calculation  and  individual  payments.  Cases  of  missing  contributions,  and  therefore  missing 
investment  returns  on  the  GPF,  are  widespread.  Moreover,  there  is  no  formal  channel  for 
inquiries or appeals by pensioners when such errors and omissions occur.   
 
The  process  of  pension  disbursement  is  costly  due  to  cumbersome  application  and 
23. 
identification  requirements,  and  often  long  queues  in  rural  areas  of  NBP  branches  due  to 
inadequate staff. The present system generates payment notice to the authorized NBP branch 
on a transaction-by-transaction basis, and does not include monthly authorized allocation. This 
not  only  further  increases  the  cost of  pension disbursement,  but  also makes  the system  more 
error-prone.  There  is  no  mechanism  for  triggering  an  action  when  questionable  transactions 
occur. This results in significant leakages from the system in the form of “ghost” pensioners.  
 
24.  Weaknesses  in  Benefit  Structure.  Certain  features  of  the  current  pension  scheme 
have  led  to  inequitable  and  arbitrary  outcomes  among  individual  employees.  For  instance, 
calculating pensions on the basis of the last pay drawn by an employee can favor those who get 
a salary increase or a promotion immediately before retirement. The international best practice  
is to base pensions on average earnings over several years. Increases in pension benefits, to 
compensate  for  changes  in  the  cost  of  living,  are  ad  hoc  and  often  trail  inflation.  Interest 
payments  by  the  government  on  employees’  GPF  contributions  are  likewise  unpredictable. 
Currently, up to 35% of the pension can be commuted and taken as a lump sum, while the rest 
is paid as an annuity until death. The commutation allowance is high by international standards, 
and may not be consistent with the public policy objective of facilitating consumption-smoothing 
and ensuring adequate old-age income for civil servants. 
 
Since  2005,  most  civil  servants  have  been  contractual  employees  without  pension and 
25. 
GPF  benefits.  More  than  50,000  employees  thus  far  have  been  affected  by  this  arrangement, 
which  has  raised  concerns  about  workplace  morale,  and  the  longer-term  social  and  economic 
implications  of  having  a  significant  proportion  of  civil  servants  with  little  or  no  savings  and  no 
pension benefits. 
 

3. 

Need for a More Merit-Based and Accountable Civil Service 

Background.  The  public  sector  employs  about  11%  of  employed  workers  in  the 
26. 
province,  including  about  967,000  in  sanctioned  posts  in  government  departments  and  the 
100,000-plus  employees  of  the  123  public  sector  autonomous  bodies.  While  this  share  is 
moderate, it understates the importance of the public sector as a major formal sector employer, 
since about 60% of all employees are self-employed. The civil service wage bill and pensions 
account for about 59% of total consolidated recurrent expenditure. The need to reform the civil 
service has been felt at both national and provincial levels. Despite various attempts at reform, 
the system is commonly perceived to be the same holdover from Pakistan’s colonial past. Some 
of the issues related to public sector employment in the Punjab are discussed below. 
 
27.  Weak  Recruitment,  Performance  Evaluation,  and  Promotion.  The  Punjab  Public 
Service Commission (PPSC) recruits public servants for basic pay scale (BPS) 1713 and above. 
The  structural,  capacity,  and  procedural  constraints  on  the  functioning  of  the  commission  are 
widely  acknowledged.  Performance  evaluation  has  also  not  been  an  effective  tool  for 
performance  monitoring.  A  large  proportion  of  civil  servants  do  not  have  job  descriptions,  let 
                                                 
13 The civil service of Pakistan is structured across twenty two basic pay scales (BPS 1-22). With some exceptions, 
the government officers of BPS 17 and higher are categorized as gazetted officers and assigned middle to senior 
level managerial responsibilities such as heads of sections, departments, field offices and drawing and disbursing 
officers. Government servants below BPS 17 generally work as support staff. 

 

 alone  targets  for  achievement.  The  annual  confidential  report,  instead  of  being  a  performance 
evaluation  record,  is  commonly  regarded  as  a  compliance  task.  Moreover,  performance 
evaluations play a limited role in career progression in a system in which promotions are largely 
based on seniority.  
 
28. 
Uncompetitive  Compensation  and  Benefits.  There  is  substantial  evidence  that  the 
real  compensation  gap  between  public  and  private  salaries  and  emoluments  has  steadily 
widened.  In  addition,  the  wage  structure  is  not  closely  linked  to  performance  and  does  not 
provide  adequate  incentives  for  good  performance.  The  provincial  government  has  no  control 
over  civil  service  salary  scales,  which  are  set  by  the  federal  Government.  It  can,  however, 
create  contract  positions  outside  the  cadre  scales  or  pay  additional  allowances  for  specific 
positions.  For  example,  program  management  units  (PMUs)  have  been  used  as  a  device  to 
create  specific  positions  attracting  higher  reward.  There  is some  evidence  suggesting  that  the 
recruitment  and  remuneration  practice  of  PMUs  has  strengthened  performance  incentives. 
PMUs thus should be seen as a testing case and precursor for introducing performance-based 
human resource management in the civil service of the province. 
 
29. 
Achievement  and  Sustainability  of  the  Contractual  Employment  System.  Civil 
services  reforms  are  a  challenging  task  for  any  government.  Despite  this,  the  GoPb  has 
implemented  some  important  measures.  One  major  reform  initiative  since  2003  has  been  the 
shift  toward  contract  employment  for  fresh  entrants  into  government  service.  Contractual 
employees are paid 30% above the minimum salary of the relevant pay scale as compensation 
for not being eligible for pension. However, the difference in compensation between regular and 
contract  employees  is  not  large  enough  to  discourage  employees  from  seeking  regularization. 
The pressure to regularize contract employees is building up as their numbers increase.  
 
30. 
Frequent  Transfers.  There  are  no  systematic  policies  or  mechanisms  for  placements 
and transfers. In many cases, the process lacks a professional and technical basis, leading to a 
mismatch  between  skills  and  placement.  Transfers  are  often  made  within  a  year  of  service, 
rather  than  the  recommended  minimum  of  2–3  years.  As  such,  the  incumbents  often  barely 
have time to settle into a new job before they are moved on. 
 
31.  Weak  Technical  and  Managerial  Skills.  A  World  Bank  report 14 points  out  that  the 
technical  competence  of  civil  servants  in  the  Punjab  has  been  declining  over  the  past  two 
decades. The training of civil servants also draws little interest because of its low returns. The 
GoPb has, however, increased its efforts in the training area in recent years. Supported by the 
PRMP, the government entered into a short-term arrangement with the Singapore Civil Service 
College to undertake various training programs. Such efforts mark an encouraging step toward 
improving  the  capacity  of  civil  servants.  However,  much  remains  to  be  done  to  upgrade  the 
capacity, incentives, and accountability of the system. 
 
32. 
Challenges  Posed  by  Devolution.  The  Punjab  Local  Government  Ordinance  of 2001 
(PLGO)  launched  the  process  of  devolution  and  significantly  changed  intergovernmental 
relationships.  Given  the  relatively  short  time  that  has  passed  since  then,  there  is  continuing 
confusion over the roles, functions, and mandates of the different levels of government and the 
mechanisms for coordination between departments and agencies. The lack of capacity in local

government for such key functions as planning, budgeting, and human resource management is 
also a major constraint on the effective functioning of this level of government. 
 

4. 

Need for Dynamic Private Sector–Led Growth and Public-Private 
Partnerships  

33. 
Background. The Punjab economy has sustained GDP growth rates of more than 6% 
per  year  since  2003.  Investment  rates  have  recovered  in  recent  years.  The  agriculture  and 
service sectors have been performing well and the Punjab has attracted a major share of recent 
foreign direct investment inflow. The province has thus been able to generate new employment 
opportunities, and to reduce poverty significantly. The private sector still operates mostly in the 
informal  sector,  as  the  high  cost  of  doing  business  presents  a  significant  barrier  to  entry.  The 
government,  on  the  other  hand,  recognizes  that  it  cannot  meet  on  its  own  the  significant 
investment requirements in infrastructure and other services. The remaining challenges include 
the following: 
 
Unclear  Role  of  the  GoPb  in  Private  Sector  Development.  The  role  of  the 
34. 
government in private sector development  must be better defined. It must be clarified that the 
government  is  expected  to  (i)  formulate  and  implement  laws,  rules,  and  procedures  to  govern 
the  functions  of  the  private  sector;  (ii)  make  the  regulatory  framework  more  efficient  and 
effective, (iii) provide infrastructure facilities; (iv) provide social sector services; and (v) resolve 
issues  related  to  the  provision  and  the  treatment  of  public  goods,  as  well  as  collective  action 
issues that affect key sectors in the provincial economy.  
 
35.  Weak  Prioritization  and  Coordination  of  Policy  for  Private  Sector  Development. 
Private  sector  development  initiatives  and  measures  intended  to  give  the  private  sector  a 
greater  role  in service delivery  are  poorly  coordinated.  The  GoPb  lacks  a  coherent  strategy  in 
this  area.  There  have  so  far  been  only  limited  attempts  to  assess  public  sector  support,  to 
prioritize activities and improve their coordination, and to identify gaps in policy objectives and 
program implementation. 
 
36. 
High  Regulatory  and  Compliance  Costs  of  Doing  Business  in  the  Punjab. 
Regulatory and compliance costs continue to be major concerns for businesses in the Punjab. 
While costs and time involved have gone down in areas like business start-up and closure, and 
import and  export administration, they are a persistent challenge in other  areas  like  access  to 
credit,  contract  enforcement,  and  infrastructure  (electricity,  water  and  sanitation,  roads, 
transport). The government must benchmark the direct and indirect costs of doing business, and 
undertake effective assessments of the benefits and costs of regulation.  
 
37.  Weak Compliance of Firms with International Standards. The private sector is losing 
out to competitors in the region because it fails to comply with international standards for labor, 
environmental  protection,  and  quality.  The  private  sector  must  become  better  informed  about 
the legal requirements for production and export. The GoPb, for its part, should ensure that the 
information  is  disseminated,  implementing  agencies  coordinate  their  activities,  appropriate 
capacity is built, and current regulations are reviewed.   
 
38. 
Absence  of  a  Policy  and  Regulatory  Framework  for  Public-Private  Partnerships. 
Some  services  have  traditionally  been  provided  by  the  public  sector,  for  historical,  legal,  or 
economic reasons. Yet within these sectors the public sector feels that it cannot deliver services 
of the quality and quantity required to meet the demand. The government lacks the financial and 
technical resources to meet the demand in these two broad categories of services: (i) key social 

 

 10 

 

 

sector services like health and education, and (ii) infrastructure (roads, utilities, water, sanitation, 
solid waste management). In both these areas the private sector can help narrow or close the 
gap between demand and supply. PPPs can be structured effectively in such cases. However, 
the  rules  of  the  game  are  not  clear  at  present.  A  clear  policy  and  regulatory  framework  is 
needed to guide the formation of such PPPs in the Punjab.  
 
B. 

 
Lessons  

A large number of program loans have been implemented by ADB and the World Bank 
39. 
over the past decade with mixed results. These offer useful lessons for improving policy-based 
lending. ADB’s program lending in Pakistan, and particularly in the Punjab, also demonstrates 
important lessons to be reflected in the PGEIP and other proposed clusters. 
  
40. 
Using Policy Conditions as an Evolving Tool for Reforms. A review of policy-based 
lending  by  ADB  and  the  World  Bank15 shows  that  it  has  become  an  important  instrument  for 
supporting  reforms.  One  major  concern,  however,  arises  from  the  evidence  that  many  reform 
programs were structured around unrealistic conditions that were prescriptive, rigid, numerous 
yet not well prioritized, and unsoundly assessed for ownership and institutional capacity. While a 
key reason for rigid conditions was to make reforms more binding, rigidity has not been effective 
in  making  policy  changes.  Instead,  experience  has  shown  that  policy  adjustments  during 
implementation  may  be  required  by  changing  domestic  and  international  circumstances,  new 
and  better  ways  of  doing  things,  or  unforeseen  design  shortcomings.  Thus,  one  important 
lesson  is  that  policy  conditions  should  be  based  on  sound  diagnostic  analysis,  geared  to 
respond  to  evolving  circumstances,  and  structured  around  open  and  informed  debate  about 
policy reform to nurture desired changes.  
 
41. 
Improving  Integration  between  Programs.  ADB  often  supports  several  lending 
programs  to  a  country,  or  a  province  in  the  case  of  the  Punjab.  Integration  and  coordination 
between  programs  must  be  strengthened  to  reduce  duplication  and  conflicting  policy  advice. 
The integrated approach offers one clear way to achieve this objective.  
 
42. 
Securing  Political  and  Bureaucratic  Ownership.  A  prerequisite  for  successful 
program  implementation  is  strong  political  and  bureaucratic  ownership.  The  implementation  of 
the  PRMP  indicates  that  assistance  from  development  agencies  can  play  a  catalytic  role  in 
bringing  about  desired  changes.  However,  external  assistance  by  itself  cannot  substitute  for 
government commitment and actions. Thus, for effective development results, the policy agenda 
needs to be backed by broader country or provincial public sector reforms that are owned and 
driven by the government. Reforms must therefore be home-grown.   
 
43. 
Effectively  Communicating  with  the  Public  on  Reforms.  Reforms  need  to  be 
preceded  by  sensitization  and  awareness  initiatives  to  build  constituencies  for  change.  In 
particular, communication and measures that address the concerns of people who are likely to 
be  affected  by  reforms  are  necessary  to  reduce  opposition.  Program  costs  as  well  as  TA 
allocation need to explicitly factor in resources needed for communication. Broader stakeholder 
participation  is  also  needed  to  obtain  adequate  buy-in  and  to  diminish  the  influence  of  vested 
interests.

Designing  Technical  Assistance.  Policy  reforms  often  require  TA  support.  The  TA

procedures need to be simplified to increase efficiency and reduce transaction costs, while also 
building  in  strong  governance  and  accountability  mechanisms.  Establishing  an  effective 
mechanism for responding to lessons learned on TA design and implementation within ADB is 
also important.   
 
C. 

External Assistance to the Sector 

47. 
The PMU of the PRMP is mandated to coordinate all donor-funded policy programs and 
projects in the Punjab. This institutionalization of donor coordination at the provincial level has 
led  to  regular  coordination  meetings  with  all  the  development  partners  involved.  The  PMU 
belongs  to  the  provincial  Planning  and  Development  Department  and  issues  minutes  of  these 
meetings, further facilitating donor coordination.  
 
48. 
The PGEIP was designed in close coordination with other development partners. While 
the  Program  is  fully  aligned  with  the  development  strategy  of  the  GoPb  and  ADB’s  country 
strategy,  it  is  also  intended  to  complement  existing  donor  assistance.  The  Project  for 
Improvement  in  Financial  Reporting  and  Auditing  (PIFRA),  supported  by  the  World  Bank,  is 
aimed at improving the accuracy and timeliness of intra-year and year-end government financial 
and  fiscal  reports  at  the  federal,  provincial,  and  district  levels.  In  the  area  of  public  service 
delivery,  the  World  Bank’s  Punjab  Irrigation  Sector  Development  Policy  Loan  is  supporting 
reforms to (i) improve transparency and equity of water distribution, (ii) increase the participation 
and empowerment of water users in irrigation service delivery, and (iii) build the capacity of the 
Irrigation and Power Department. Likewise, the World Bank–supported Punjab Education Sector 
Reform  Program  is  aimed  at  improving  the  quality  of  education  and  improving  enrollment  and 
retention.  The  Faisalabad  Devolution  Project,  supported  by  the  Department  for  International 
Development (DFID) of the UK, seeks to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the district 
government to better meet the needs of local communities.  
 
The World Bank and DFID are also supporting tax administration reforms at the federal 
49. 
level. The World Bank’s Pakistan Tax Administration Reform Project is aimed at strengthening 
the  Central  Board  of  Revenue  to  promote  voluntary  compliance,  increased  revenue  yield,  and 
more equitable application of tax laws. The DFID-supported Tax Administration Reform Project 
seeks  to  improve  tax  administration  through  the  adoption  of  an  integrated  tax  management 
system.    Further  details  on  these  and  other  related  projects  are  in  Appendix  5,  which  also 
presents  information  on  the  support  provided  by  DFID  in  Pakistan  and  the  Punjab.  ADB  will 

 

 continue to coordinate with other development partners during implementation to avoid overlap 
and to maximize synergies. 
 
IV. 

THE PROPOSED PUNJAB GOVERNMENT EFFICIENCY IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

50. 
The  PGEIP  will  support  the  GoPb  in  realizing  its  long-term  goals  as  expressed  in  the 
Punjab  Vision  2020,  where  it  commits  to  significantly  improve  the  standard  of  living  of  the 
people of Punjab, especially the poor and the vulnerable. The proposed PGEIP will improve the 
overall functioning of the government machinery at the provincial, district, and municipal levels, 
and thereby improve the quality of public services. The high level impact of the PGEIP will be 
sustained  high  levels  of  economic  growth  resulting  in  lower  poverty  incidence  and  improved 
public services. The principal outcomes of the PGEIP will be greater efficiency in the allocation 
of scarce public resources and greater responsiveness of the government to the needs of the 
citizens. PGEIP will achieve these through reforms leading to:  
 

greater performance orientation in planning and budgeting;  
a fully funded and well-managed civil service pension system that increases the 
confidence of civil servants and the public, and generates fiscal space for high-
priority social sector investments; 
improved  efficiency  of  the  civil  service  apparatus,  with  sound  incentives  and 
merit-based appointment and career progression; and  
greater  private  sector  contribution  to  growth  and  sustainable  public-private 
partnerships. 

Built on the GoPb’s own second-generation reform agenda, the PGEIP encompasses a 

 
51. 
range of interlinked and complementary policy actions in four core policy areas (CPAs):   
 

CPA  1:  Improving  fiscal  and  financial  management  by  (a)  improving 
coordination between medium-term budgeting and planning including integration 
between  the  MTBF  and  the  MTDF,  and  between  the  annual  budget  and  the 
medium-term  budget  and  planning  framework;  (b)  increasing  the  transparency 
and  accountability  of  budget  preparation  and  execution; 
(c)  achieving 
performance orientation in annual budgeting by linking the process more closely 
with  service  delivery;  and  (d)  improving  revenue  mobilization  through  better  tax 
administration at decentralized levels in the Punjab province. 

CPA 2: Establishing a financially sustainable pension system that provides 
retirement  income  security  to  civil  servants  by  (a)  establishing  the  Punjab 
Pension  Fund  (PPF)  and  the  General  Provident  Investment  Fund  (GPIF)  to 
reduce  the  growing  fiscal  burden  of  pension  and  GPF  liabilities,  and  to  create 
fiscal  space  for  priority  development  expenditures;  (b)  improving  PPF  and  GPF 
record-keeping  and  administration  procedures  to  ensure  accurate  and  timely 
payment of benefits to pensioners; and (c) strengthening the pension system to 
enhance pension benefits and coverage, to include contractual employees.  

(iii)

institutional foundation that drives civil service reforms, (b) improving the human

Outputs and Activities 

52. 
The  design  and  monitoring  framework  for  the  overall  PGEIP  is  in  Appendix  1,  the 
development  policy  letter  is  in  Appendix  6,  and  the  policy  matrix  for  SP1  is  in  Appendix  7. 
Supplementary  Annex  D  presents  an  action  plan  that  fully  lays  out  all  the  steps  involved  in 
achieving  the  policy  actions  in  Appendix  7.  The  reform  elements  under  each  of  the  CPAs  are 
described below.  
 

1. 

Output of Core Policy Area 1: Improved Fiscal and Financial Management 

a. 

Improve Public Resource Management 

53. 
The compartmentalized approach to the preparation of medium-term plans (MTDF) and 
budgets  (MTBF)  is  a  major  obstacle  to  effective  public  financial  management.  Therefore,  a 
major objective of reform under the PGEIP will be to improve the integration between the MTBF 
and MTDF and increase the transparency and accountability of the annual budget process. This 
will  be  achieved  through  increased  cooperation  between  the  FD  and  the  P&DD  (i.e.,  central 
departments),  and  between  central  and  line  departments.  Increased  cooperation  will  further 
facilitate the integration between the top-down and the bottom-up dimensions of the MTBF and 
MTDF,  including  timely  communication  from  the  FD  to  other  departments  of  the  resources 
available  over  the  next  3  years,  improved  capacity  of  line  departments  to  appraise  and 
determine  the  cost  of  investment  projects,  better  coordination  between  FD  and  P&DD  in  the 
publication of the MTBF and MTDF, and the capacity to fully integrate the MTBF and the annual 
budget.  
  
54. 
Quality and timeliness of the MTDF and MTBF are essential to improved planning and 
budgeting.  Closer  integration  between  the  two  will  lead  to  better  prioritization  of  expenditures, 
with  emphasis  on  productive  development  spending.  While  the  MTDF  for  FY2008–2010  has 
been published, MTBF forecasts are 2 years overdue. As part of SP1, the FD has finalized the 
fiscal forecasts and publish the MTBF for the period FY2008–2010. The new MTBF will provide 
more  transparency  and  predictability  in  the  interdepartmental  allocation  of  resources.  To 
improve the coordination of the MTBF and MTDF processes, the existing MTBF cell within the 
FD  and  the  MTDF  cell  within  the  P&DD  will  be  strengthened  and  joint  protocols  will  be 
developed. This will result in clearer expenditure ceilings across line departments, and greater 
sustainability  of  development  projects  through  the  allocation  of  resources  for  recurrent 
maintenance needs. Under SP2, timely annual updating of the MTBF is supported to ensure a 
more  reliable  and  realistic  assessment  of  the  resources  available  over  the  medium  term. 
Depending on the progress of the first two SPs, a unified MTEF consolidating the planning and 
budgeting dimensions could be adopted under SP3.  
 
55. 
For the MTBF/MTDF to be a meaningful tool for the effective allocation of resources, it 
has  to  be  fully  integrated  with  the  annual  budget  process.  For  this  purpose,  under  SP1,  a 

 

 14 

 

 

revised  annual  budget  statement  format  has  been  introduced,  providing  for  an  organizational 
and economic classification of expenditures along with a functional classification in the interest 
of increased transparency in the allocation of resources. 
 
The  budget  call  circular  (BCC)  is  a  key  document,  as  it  is  circulated  by  the  FD  to  line 
56. 
departments at the start of the budget cycle for the submission of their expenditure estimates. In 
its current format, the BCC is not suited to the integration of the annual budget with the MTBF. 
Under SP2, the format of BCC will be revised and made more conducive to the full integration of 
the annual budget and the MTBF, including the notification of recurrent budget ceilings to line 
departments16 and the improvement of coordination between the FD and the P&DD.  
 
57. 
Infusing  greater  fiscal  discipline  into  public  expenditure  management  is  another 
important  objective  of  reform  under  this  component.  To  this  end,  a  policy  and  regulatory 
framework for fiscal responsibility will be developed under SP2 to promote principles of prudent 
fiscal and financial management in both central and line departments. A review of the existing 
mechanism of excess and surrenders will also be made under SP2 for the purpose of improving 
budget execution. 
  
58. 
Effective auditing is critical in ensuring accountability in the use of public resources. The 
introduction  of  performance-based  budgeting  (PBB)  has  increased  the  need  to  carry  out 
performance  auditing  in  addition  to  the  traditional  financial  auditing.  Under  SP3,  the  GoPb  is 
urged to adopt strict guidelines for the obligation of line departments to disclose audited budget 
statements and precise timelines for responding to comments raised by the auditor. When the 
PBB  is  fully  on  track,  at  least  in  the  pilot  entities,  a  performance  auditing  system  should  be 
introduced  to  enable  the  government  to  assess  the  capacity  of  line  departments  to  effectively 
meet their performance targets through budget expenditures.  
 
59. 
To  support  bottom-up  planning  within  the  context  of  devolution,  and  to  integrate 
provincial policy priorities into local governments planning, SP1 also supports the notification of 
the  Local  Government  Planning  Manual  so  that  it  can  serve  as  a  planning  tool  for  local 
governments.  Local  government  compliance  with  rules  and  procedures  set  in  the  manual  will 
pave the way for local government involvement in the MTEF effort during SP2 and SP3.        
 
60. 
Finally, the Program also seeks improved mobilization of tax revenues at both provincial 
and  local  government  levels.  It  is  aimed  at  consolidating  reform  efforts  already  undertaken 
during the PRMP in three main areas of tax policy and tax administration, namely: (i) developing 
a  provincial  database  of  stamp  duty  collection  to  improve  revenue  yields;  (ii)  supporting  the 
implementation  of  the  provincial  agriculture  income  tax  policy  to  improve  efficiency  in  the 
assessment and collection of the agriculture income tax; and (iii) improving tax administration by 
bringing all tax collection functions under a unified authority. The proposed revenue-augmenting 
measures  will  be  adopted  under  SP2  to  increase  the  fiscal  autonomy  of  the  provincial 
government  by  generating  additional  revenues.  The  Program  is  also  aimed  at  improving  local 
government  capacity  for  revenue  administration  through  better  coordination  with  the  provincial 
government in tax policy formulation and administration.

b. 

Performance-Oriented Annual Budgeting 

61. 
The  introduction  of  performance  orientation  in  the  budget  process  is  an  important  step 
toward improving the quality of service delivery and implementing a full-fledged MTEF. This step 
requires a clear definition of service delivery standards, identification of performance indicators 
against the standards, and assessment of the costs related to the provision of services. Against 
this backdrop, steps towards PBB has been launched in a small number of pilot departments in 
SP1,  and  will  be  rolled  out  to  more  departments  in  SP2  and  SP3.  The  Department  of  Health  
(DOH) and the Department of Irrigation and Power (DI&P) will be the pilot departments. Under 
SP1,  an  SPU  has  been  strengthened  within  DOH.  It  will  be  responsible  for  defining  sector 
policies and strategies, and for estimating the resources needed to implement these strategies. 
DI&P has established a new MTEF committee to harmonize the strategic spending priorities of 
the department and coordinate with the central MTBF/MTDF cells in MTBF/MTDF preparation. 
More line departments will set up SPUs under SP2. 
 
62. 
A necessary condition for the effective introduction of PBB is that pilot entities undertake 
a strategic review of their medium-term investment portfolio and recurrent expenditure pattern. 
SP2 will support a departmental expenditure review in both DOH and DI&P to assess whether 
the  existing  allocation  of  resources  is  in  line  with  the  medium-term  strategic  goals  of  the 
departments,  and  to  identify  the  scope  for  rationalizing  resource  allocation.  The  ultimate 
purpose  of  the  expenditure  review  is  to  make  resource  allocations  more  consistent  with  the 
desired service delivery standards, and hence more efficient in the achievement of the MDGs, 
especially those related to education and health.   
 
To  obtain  public  feedback  on  the  quality  of  public  services  and  enable  a  closer  match 
63. 
between  the  quality  and  level  of  service  delivery  and  citizens’  needs,  a  citizen  satisfaction 
survey will be designed and carried out under SP2. The first round will be conducted in selected 
district  governments,  such  as  those  where  the  minimum  service  delivery  standards  for  health-
care services will be pilot-tested under the PDSSP.  
 

2. 

Output of Core Policy Area 2: Civil Service Pension Reform 

The PGEIP will support the development of a financially sustainable pension system that 
64. 
provides  adequate  and  equitable  retirement  income  for  civil  servants.  The  establishment  of  a 
funded  pension  system  will  create  fiscal  space  for  pro-poor  public  expenditures,  and  foster 
productive  investment  and  financial  sector  development  over  the  longer  term  by  promoting 
contractual savings and asset accumulation. In addition, Punjab’s pension reforms could serve 
as a catalytic model for reforms at the federal level and in other provinces. 
 

a. 

Establishment of the Punjab Pension Fund and the General 
Provident Investment Fund 

65. 
The  objective  of  this  component  is  to  reduce  the  growing  burden  of  pension  and  GPF 
liabilities  on  the  finances  of  the  GoPb,  and  to  create  fiscal  space  for  priority  development 
expenditures.  To  this  end,  the  Program  will  support  the  establishment  of  professionally 
managed  funds  to  meet  pension  obligations.  With  adequate  capitalization  and  a  prudent 
investment  strategy,  it  is  expected  that  the  PPF  and  the  GPIF  will  generate  sufficient  returns 
over time to finance the pension and GPF obligations.   
 
66. 
The PPF Act passed by the provincial assembly in March 2007 requires that the PPF be 
managed  by  a  management  committee  comprising  six  ex-officio  members,  four  private  sector 

 

 16 

 

 

representatives,  and  a  general  manager.  Under  SP1,  the  GoPb  has  established  the 
management  committee,  and  developed  and  adopted  the  PPF  implementing  rules  covering 
fiduciary arrangements, exposure limits and risk management, accounting and auditing, internal 
controls, and compliance.  
 
67. 
To  date,  the  government  has  earmarked  PRs8  billion  for  the  capitalization  of  the  PPF 
and  PRs4  billion  for  GPIF.  Under  SP1,  it  has  undertaken  an  actuarial  valuation  of  pension 
liabilities, prepared a funding strategy for capitalizing the PPF and the GPIF. The strategy takes 
into account the magnitude of pension liabilities, possible sources of funds (including provincial 
revenues, donor funds, and privatization proceeds), and the province’s development needs. To 
minimize  operational  costs,  avoid  duplicating  efforts,  share  professional  expertise,  and  take 
advantage of economies of scale, it is envisaged that the management committee for the PPF 
will also manage the GPIF. 
 
68. 
The  GoPb  will  set  up  the  GPIF  and  its  investment  operations  in  2008.  Building  on  the 
rules  developed  under  SP1,  the  government  will  establish  fiduciary  arrangements  and  risk 
management  systems  and  procedures  for  the  PPF  and  the  GPIF.  Key  actions  in  this  regard 
include: (i) selecting investment managers and investment advisers; (ii) appointing a compliance 
officer  and  an  external  auditor;  (iii)  establishing  audit,  accounting,  and  risk  controls;  and  (iv) 
establishing compliance, reporting, and disclosure systems. 

 

b. 

Improved Pension and General Provident Fund Record-Keeping and 
Payment Systems and Procedures  

The  purpose  of  this  subcomponent  is  to  ensure  the  accurate  and  timely  payment  of 
69. 
benefits  to  pensioners.  A  reliable  record-keeping  system,  including  information  technology- 
management information system (IT-MIS) that enables the flow of data and information among 
the  FD,  the  Office  of  the  AGP,  and  payment  agents,  is  a  prerequisite  for  a  credible  pension 
system.  Effective  mechanisms  for  verifying  claims  to  minimize  inaccurate  and  fraudulent 
transactions need to be put in place to reduce leakages in the system. The institutional capacity 
of the Office of the AGP to ensure system soundness must also be strengthened. 
 
 As  the  first  step  toward  improving  pension  administration,  the  GoPb  has  prepared  a 
70. 
policy  note  identifying  the  key  weaknesses  in  the  existing  system.  It  has  also  appointed  a 
Pension Administration Taskforce (PAT) comprising representatives from the FD and the Office 
of  the  AGP.  PAT  will  conduct  an  in-depth  assessment  of  the  administrative  arrangements, 
including the functioning of payment agents, to reduce fraud and errors, as well as streamline 
the procedures for pension disbursement. On the basis of the assessment, PAT will recommend 
measures  to  improve  record-keeping  and  overall  system  administration,  leading  to  swift 
processing of pension payments with minimal errors. SP2 and SP3 of PGEIP will also support 
the  implementation  of  PAT’s  recommendations,  including  the  establishment  of  the  IT-MIS  and 
capacity-building measures. 
 

c. 

Improved Pension System     

The  objective  of  this  component  is  to  introduce  parametric  and  systemic17 reforms  to 
71. 
enhance  pension  benefits  and  coverage  while  ensuring  the  financial  sustainability  of  the 

                                                 
17 Parametric  reforms  involve  modifications  in  various  parameters  such  as  retirement  age,  contribution  rate,  among

17

pension system. The current pension system was developed in the 1960s and 1970s, and, while 
some revisions have been made more recently, there is a need for a comprehensive review to

will  evaluate  the  overall  retirement  saving  scheme,  covering  the  retirement  age,  length  of

retirement  saving  options  for  contractual  civil  servants  will  be  developed.  Taking  international 
experience and relevant case studies into account, the GoPb will also explore the prospects for 
introducing  a  multi-pillar  pension  system  comprising  a  minimum  government-guaranteed
