regulatory framework for the parametric and systemic reforms will be developed under SP3. 

 
3. 

Output of Core Policy Area 3: Civil Service Reforms 

72.  With 40 departments, 35 districts, and hundreds of municipal administrations, and, most 
importantly, one million civil servants in its employ and a client base of over 80 million people, 
the  civil  service  machinery  of  the  GoPb  must  be  well  structured  and  have  efficient  business 
processes. The objectives of this CPA are to support the government’s efforts in making the civil 
service more efficient, effective, and responsive by improving the human resource management 
system, policies, rules, procedures, and practices. The improvements will in turn (i) enhance the 
capacity of the government to perform its functions; (ii) make the government a better employer, 
better  able  to  attract  and  retain  competent  staff;  (iii)  lift  the  morale  of  civil  servants;  and  (iv) 
ultimately lead to improved public services for the benefit of the people in the Punjab.     
 

a. 

An Institutional Foundation for Civil Service Reform 

the 

in  SP1  address 

institutional  arrangements.  Three  actions 

73. 
Civil  service  reform  (CSR),  by  virtue  of  its  complexity,  requires  strong  leadership,  and 
institutional 
supportive 
requirements  at  different  levels.  First,  the  GoPb  has  established  a  high-powered  task  force  to 
lead,  guide,  and  oversee  reforms.  The  Civil  Service  Modernization  and  Reform  Task  Force 
(CSMRTF) will be chaired by the Chief Secretary. To balance effectiveness against the need for 
wide  participation,  CSMRTF  will  have  about  11 members,  including  representatives  from  civil 
society. CSMRTF will produce a document clearly expressing its vision for civil service reforms 
in the coming years.  
  
Second,  to  steer  the  reforms,  the  GoPb  has  significantly  strengthened  its  Change 
74. 
Management Unit (CMU) by increasing its resources and mandate—it is now the Public Policy 
and  Change  Management  Wing  (PPCMW)  of  the  Service  and  General  Administration 
Department (S&GAD). A senior civil servant is full-time head of the PPCMW, which serves as 
CSMRTF secretariat and provides technical and operational support to the CSMRTF. PPCMW 
is the second tier of the institutional foundation for CSR.  
 
75. 
Third,  the  GoPb  has  appointed  change  management  agents  in  all  40 provincial 
departments and 35 districts to coordinate the CSR and capacity-building activities. This move 
strengthens the linkage between the CSMRTF, the PPCMW, and the departments and districts. 
The change management agents constitute the third tier of the CSR institutional foundation.  
 

 

 b. 

Improved Human Resource Management System for Civil Servants  

76. 
Serving over 80 million people effectively calls for sound human resource management 
(HRM) systems and policies in the civil service. While the GoPb has pioneered some innovative 
measures  like  the  contractual  employment  system  and  the  strengthening  of  its  provincial  civil 
service  cadre,  its  policies  and  rules  need  updating.  The  government  has  therefore  begun  a 
review  of  key  civil  service  human  resource  management  policies,  including  the  Punjab  Civil 
Service  Act  (1974),  the  Punjab  Contract  Appointment  Policy  (2004),  and  the  Provincial 
Management Service Rules (2003). The Punjab Civil Service Act (1974) has been in place for 
over three decades now and urgently needs review and updating. The government introduced 
the contractual employment system in 2004, to deal with endemic absenteeism among regular 
staff,  especially  in  the  education  and  health  departments;  disincentives  to  good  performance, 
owing to security of tenure; problems relating to automatic promotions based on seniority; and 
the complicated nature and ineffectiveness of the existing disciplinary rules and mechanisms for 
holding  regular  government  employees  accountable.  However,  there  are  concerns  about  the 
sustainability  of  the  contract  employment  system,  which  call  for  a  review  of  the  system  to 
sustain  the  gains  made  thus  far.  A  key  issue  relates  to  pension  provision  for  contract 
employment.  
 
77. 
The  government  has  recruited  the  first  batch  of  civil  servants  under  the  enhanced 
Provincial  Management  Service  (PMS),  which  combines  two  parallel  provincial  civil  service 
streams. The PMS is a critical part of the civil service system, as the bulk of the positions are 
middle-management  district  officer  positions,  directly  in  charge  of  service  delivery  at  local 
government levels. While it has taken the good step of setting up the PMS, the GoPb needs to 
ensure the career management of the PMS staff vis-à-vis those civil servants that are appointed 
by  the  federal  Government.  Without  an  HRM  system  that  rewards  performance  and  exacts 
adequate accountability, the PMS runs the risk of suffering from established systemic problems. 
The PGEIP will provide continuous support in getting the incentives right for the PMS.  
 
78. 
Rapid change will not be desirable in a civil service one million strong. Hence, the GoPb 
will  pilot-test  changes  in  the  HRM  system  in  eight  departments,  before  moving  toward  greater 
performance  orientation.  The  pilot  will  be  aimed  at  promoting  transparent  and  merit-based 
recruitment  and  promotion  systems,  performance-oriented  compensation,  and  greater 
accountability  of  civil  servants.  A  Punjab  Civil  Servant  Human  Resource  Management  Manual 
will  be  developed  under  SP2,  and  related  training  will  be  carried  out  for  both  provincial 
departments and local governments.  
 
79. 
Given the problems faced by the PPSC (para. 27), the government intends to strengthen 
its  structure  and  functioning,  as  an  improved  PPSC  is  essential  for  increasing  flexibility  and 
efficiency, as well as safeguarding the integrity of civil service recruitment. 
 

c. 

Improved Government Functions and Streamlined Business 
Processes 

The government is committed to taking two key steps to improve the functioning of the 
80. 
civil service. First, it will appoint about 10 senior civil servants to principal secretary positions, to 
help  coordinate  service  delivery.  All  heads  of  provincial  and  district  departments  and 
corporatized agencies now report to the chief secretary in all policy and administrative matters. 
The government recognizes that such a system is unsustainable. The principal secretaries will 
act  as  the  middle  layer  and  ensure  smoother  interdepartmental  and  province-district 
coordination. Second, before initiating any system-wide restructuring, the government identified 

18 

 

 

  

 

19

a few key departments that will undergo a full-fledged functional review and a reengineering of 
their business processes. The PGEIP will support progress on both fronts and deepen reforms.  
 

d. 

Strengthened Capacity of Civil Servants 

81. 
To improve its in-house training capacity, the GoPb is collaborating with the Singapore 
Civil  Service  College  to  modernize  its  MPDD.  As  part  of  this  effort,  the  MPDD  has  been 
upgraded  to  the  principal  training  and  capacity-building  arm  of  the  Punjab  civil  service.  The 
MPDD  has  developed  a  training  framework  to  guide  capacity-building  activities  for  the  civil 
service in the province. The PGEIP and the associated TA loan will support a range of initiatives 
under this subcomponent. 
 

4. 

Output of Core Policy Area 4: Private Sector Development 

a. 

Dynamic Private Sector–Led Growth 

The private sector reform initiatives under PRMP were largely stand-alone interventions 
82. 
with a limited strategic view of how best to foster private sector–led growth. Under the PGEIP, 
the development of a well-defined private sector development strategy will form a major building 
block  for  SP1  and  SP2.  The  GoPb  will  consult  closely  with  the  private  sector,  and  develop  a 
strategy  with  a  clear  road  map  for  the  role  of  the  public  sector  in  fostering  private  sector–led 
growth.  This  will  be  achieved  under  the  direction  of  a  private  sector  development  (PSD) 
committee, which will coordinate policy initiatives and streamline government policy across the 
relevant departments.  
 
83. 
In parallel, the government will also take specific measures to promote PSD. First, it has 
put in place an effective strategy for communicating to enterprises in the provinces the need to 
comply with core labor and international quality and environmental standards. It will also review 
the current norms in place in the Punjab and take measures to close the gap between provincial 
and  international  requirements.  Second,  the  government  will  institute  a  regular  survey  on  the 
cost  of  doing  business  in  the  Punjab.  The  survey  will  (i)  set  benchmarks  for  performance, 
(ii) allow  tracking  of  costs  and  of  progress  made,  and  (iii)  allow  regular  and  continuous 
assessment  of  relevant  issues.  It  will  identify  the  key  problem  areas  and  allow  the  GoPb  to 
address the legal and institutional reforms needed to bring down the cost of doing business. The 
government  will  also  institutionalize  a  regulatory  impact  assessment  mechanism  in  relevant 
departments. 
 

b. 

Public-Private Partnerships 

84. 
For  PPP  arrangements  to  be  effective,  there  needs  to  be  a  comprehensive  legal  and 
regulatory  framework  and  mechanisms.  To  initiate  this  process  and  to  coordinate  overall  PPP 
implementation, the government has created a PPP cell in the P&DD with clear tasks, given the 
complexity,  lack  of  understanding,  and  multiple  actors  involved.  The  government  will  also 
prepare a risk management framework and establish funding mechanisms to provide resources 
that will reduce the viability gap in projects. The government is expected to identify a number of 
PPP opportunities and to implement the regulatory framework adopted throughout the PGEIP.

C. 

Important Features 

Close Alignment with the Reform Agenda of Government. The PGEIP is fully aligned 
86. 
with the GoPb’s long-term development vision and second-generation reforms, and makes use 
of the synergy between long-term goals, medium-term milestones, and short-term actions. It has 
been  developed  through  widespread  consultation  and  consensus  building,  thus  laying  a  solid 
foundation for its successful implementation.  
 
87. 
Flexible  Policy  Triggers  with  a  Concrete  and  Evolving  Action  Plan.  The  PGEIP 
adopts a flexible approach by defining indicative triggers, while supporting a detailed action plan 
to  aid  implementation,  monitor  output,  and  sustain  the  momentum  of  reform.  The  action  plan 
clearly  sets  out  the  role  and  responsibilities  of  each  IA,  and  spells  out  the  expected  steps 
required from the start of the Program. The action plan for each SP is a living document that can 
be  adjusted  to  best  suit  the  requirements  of  reforms.  This  two-pronged  approach  effectively 
addresses the flexibility and accountability requirements.  
   
88. 
Single-Tranche  Modality.  The  move  to  adopt  single-tranche  operations  reflects  the 
lessons learned from the policy-lending experience of ADB and the World Bank. This modality 
enables the adjustment of short-term actions to achieve medium-term outcomes and long-term 
goals.  This  linkage  between  short-term  actions,  medium-term  outcomes,  and  long-term  goals 
puts  short-term  actions  on  a  sound  footing.  On  the  other  hand,  the  identification  of  short-term 
actions  makes  reforms  “implementable”  and  helps  reduce  information  requirements  and 
uncertainty.  The  emphasis  on  completing  reform  actions  before  processing  the  next  SP  also 
puts in place strong accountability for both the government and the development agencies. This 
approach also effectively integrates program processing with program implementation, such that 
reforms  take  place  through  continuous  policy  dialogue.  This  contrasts  with  the  traditional 
multi-tranche  approach,  which  compartmentalizes  the  processing  and  implementation  of 
programs, leaving little room for improvement during program implementation. 
 
89. 
Institutional Development. While the PGEIP emphasizes the achievement of outcomes, 
it also recognizes that outputs and outcomes in the public sector cannot always be measured. It 
thus  pays  special  attention  to  putting  in  place  procedures,  processes,  and  systems  to  ensure 

 

 effective output and outcome. It also strengthens institutional coordination between departments 
such as FD and P&DD, as well as between the EA and IAs.  
 
90. 
Combination  of  Diagnostic  Studies,  Policy  Changes,  and  Pilot-Testing.  The 
Program  adopts  a  programmatic  approach,  which  combines  measures  based  on 
comprehensive  analysis  with  an 
implementation. 
Pilot-testing,  rather  than  across-the-board  actions,  is  proposed,  to  bring  about  sustainable 
change.  
 
D. 

“opportunistic”  approach 

Financing Plan 

to  change 

91. 
Loan  Size,  Terms,  and  Conditions.  The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of 
$250 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to finance SP1 of the PGEIP, with interest to 
be determined according to ADB's London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)–based lending facility; 
a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years; and other terms and conditions substantially 
in accordance with those set forth in the draft program loan agreement presented to the Board. 
The Government has decided on its own to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility, 
and it has made an undertaking to the effect that this choice was not made on the basis of any 
advice from ADB. Interest rate and currency conversion options may be exercised according to 
the terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement, the loan regulations, and ADB’s 
conversion guidelines. 
 
92. 
The following factors have been taken into account in determining the loan size: (i) the 
strength  of  the  Program  and  its  development  impact,  (ii)  the  financial  and  political  cost 
associated with the implementation of the Program, and (iii) the overall development financing 
needs estimated by the FD of the GoPb. 
 
93. 
The  principal  driver  in  the  government’s  decision  to  seek  ADB’s  policy  reform  and 
financing  support  is  to  accelerate  the  funding  of  the  civil  service  pension  system.  The 
government looks forward to funding the pension system, and for this it will require a massive 
infusion of at least PRs100 billion ($1.7 billion) by FY2015–2016. It plans to invest these funds 
in a prudent manner to meet the annual pension outlays. Against this need, the government has 
sought about $300 million in program lending disbursements every year over FY2007–2011.  
 
94. 
Effective public resource management is a key contributor to economic efficiency, broad-
based economic growth, employment creation, poverty reduction, and social progress. Reforms 
in  all  the  four  core  policy  areas  of  the  PGEIP  are  essential  for  providing  good  governance, 
creating  fiscal  space,  reducing  waste,  improving  value  for  money  in  public  finance,  and 
improving  public  service  delivery.  Reforms  under  the  PGEIP  are  crucial  in  sustaining 
development in the Punjab, and the opportunity cost of not undertaking reforms will be very high. 
The  financial  and  economic  costs  associated  with  the  reforms  are  expected  to  be  substantial, 
given  the  scope  of  the  reforms.  Political  costs  are  considerable,  as  initiatives  such  as  civil 
service  reforms  will  significantly  shake  up  the  vested  interests  that  benefit  from  weak 
governance.  Direct  adjustment  costs  include  the  following:  (i)  capitalization  of  PPF  and  GPIF, 
(ii) implementation costs to improve public financial management systems, (iii) increased wage 
costs as civil service reforms bring compensation more in line with the market rate, (iv) costs to 
leverage reforms that may face resistance through consensus building, and (v) reduced revenue 
to the government due to lower compliance costs. While there are costs associated with reforms 
in the short run, the eventual economic benefits will greatly outweigh the costs in the long run.

present  of  value  of  provincial  public  debt  as  a  percentage  of  provincial  GDP  will  decline  from 
1.9% in FY2006 to 1% in FY2010.18

Program Management 

The  P&DD  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  PGEIP.  The  high-level  steering 
97. 
committee  chaired  by  the  chief  secretary  and  comprising  as  members,  the  Planning  and 
Development (P&D) chairman, additional chief secretary S&GAD, finance secretary, secretaries 
of IAs, and at least three representatives of civil society and the private sector, will guide PGEIP

decisions  and  recommendations  on  the  PRMP  website.  Since  the  steering  committee  is  large

IAs,  the  executive  committee  will  also  include  IAs  working  on  the  specific  reform  area. 
Membership  will  thus  change  according  to  the  specific  area  covered.  ADB  may  be  invited  to 
participate in the executive committee meetings as an observer.

Procurement and Disbursement Arrangements  

 
104.  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign  exchange  costs  (excluding 
local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured in ADB member countries, excluding the 
items  specified  in  the  negative  list  of  ineligible  items  (and  imports20 financed  by  other  bilateral 
and  multilateral  sources).  In  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  ADB’s  Simplification  of 
Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans,21 the proceeds of the 
program  loan  will  be  disbursed  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  as  the  Borrower.  No 
supporting import documentation will be required if, during each year that the loan proceeds are 
expected to be disbursed, the value of Pakistan’s total imports minus imports from nonmember 
countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed under other official development assistance is 
equal to or greater than the amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during that year. The 
Government  of  Pakistan  will  certify  its  compliance  with  this  formula  with  each  withdrawal 
request.  Otherwise,  import  documentation  under  existing  procedures  will  be  required. 
Disbursements will be made under the simplified procedures for program loans.

Objectives 

111.  The  objective  of  the  TA  loan  is  to  support  the  implementation  of  reforms  under  the 
PGEIP.  Specifically,  the  TA  will  support  policy  advice,  diagnostic  studies,  stakeholder 
consultations,  and  capacity  building  to  achieve  (i)  greater  performance  orientation  in  planning

and budgeting, (ii) a financially stable and adequate pension system with improved benefits and 
wider coverage, (iii) an efficient and effective civil service, and (iv) a dynamic private sector.  
 

2. 

Methodology and Activities 

112. 
 In  line  with  the  scope  of  the  PGEIP,  the  TA  loan  has  five  components:  (i)  fiscal  and 
financial  management,  (ii)  pension  reform,  (iii)  civil  service  reform,  (iv)  private  sector 
development,  and  (v)  reform  monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  TA  activities  are  divided  into 
(i) operational support, including equipment and related software; (ii) studies and assessments; 
and  (iii)  training  and  capacity  building.  Appendix  9  presents  the  full  details  of  the  TA  loan 
components, and Supplementary Appendix F presents the terms of reference for the consulting 
services.

B. 

Technical Assistance Grants 

127.  Advisory Technical Assistance (ADTA). With several stakeholders for each CPA, an 
advisory TA grant is proposed to provide expert assistance to the EA and key IAs in program 
coordination,  as  well  as  in  program  and  TA  loan  monitoring  and  evaluation.  Independent 
advisory support to the provincial government in establishing sound fiduciary arrangements for 
the pension system, and to the PPCMW in initiating and monitoring CSR measures, will also be 
provided. The total cost of the TA grant is estimated at $1.2 million equivalent. ADB will finance 
$950,000  equivalent  on  a  grant  basis  from  its  TA  funding  program  to  cover  the  consulting 
services  and  the  cost  of  training,  seminars,  and  workshops.  The  government’s  in-kind 
contribution will be $250,000 equivalent. Details of the TA grant are in Appendix 10. 
 
128.  Program  Preparatory  Technical  Assistance  (PPTA).  The  GoPb  has  also  requested 
ADB  for  TA  to  support  the  preparation  of  the  PMDGP  and  PAJP  clusters.  The  TA  will  cover 
diagnostic  assessments  of  the  constraints  impeding  social  service  delivery  in  the  Punjab,  and 
priority  policy,  regulatory,  and  institutional  actions  to  accelerate  the  attainment  of  the  MDGs, 
particularly those related to health care. It will also help establish an effective interface between 
the administrative and judicial institutions, and facilitate dialogue between the two sides, leading 
to  the  design  of  policy,  legal,  and  institutional  reforms  to  enhance  access  to  justice  in  the 
province. The total cost of the TA grant is estimated at $1.125 million equivalent, of which ADB 
has been requested by the GoPb to finance $900,000 equivalent from its TA funding program. 
Details of the PPTA grant are in Appendix 11. Appendix 12 presents a combined procurement 
plan for the TA loan and the two TA grants. 
 
129.  Advance  Contracting.  To  expedite  Program  implementation,  advance  contracting  will 
be  undertaken  to  cover  the  engagement  of  consultants  under  the  ADTA  and  the  PPTA. 
Advance action will include advertisements of consulting requirements for various components, 
and  short-listing  and  recruitments  of  individual  consultants.  GoPb  was  informed  that  ADB’s 
approval  of  the  advance  action  is  subject  to  approval  of  the  proposed  loans  and  grants  and 
does not commit ADB to finance the Program, the TA loan or the related recruitment costs.

B. 

Program Impact 

132.  Economic and Poverty Impact. The Program is expected to create significant positive 
economic  impact  in  the  medium  to  long  term.  Improved  public  financial  management  will 
improve  efficiency,  increase  value  for  money  of  public  spending,  and  generate  resources  for 
investment  and  development  spending.  The  establishment  of  the  PPF  and  GPIF  will  directly 
contribute  to  investment  and  economic  growth.  The  efficiency  gains  achieved  through  civil 
service reforms and private sector development will further lead to productivity growth, and thus 
sustainable  economic  growth.  The  Program  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  through 
economic  growth.  It  will  also  directly  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  through  resources 
generated for social and development spending, and through a more effective public sector that 
is geared toward service delivery outcomes. 
     
133. 
Institutional Impact. The PGEIP will contribute to institutional enhancement. Increased 
coordination  between  planning  and  budgeting  will  promote  a  more  holistic  approach  to  public 
financial 
expenditure  management,  with  significant  gains 
management.  The  establishment  of  a  professionally  managed  PPF  and  GPF  will  represent  a 
key milestone, and could potentially serve as a catalytic model for similar reforms at the federal 
level  and  in  other  provinces.  Civil  service  reforms  will  bring  across-the-board  institutional 
development  in  the  public  sector.  Efforts  to  promote  private  sector  development,  such  as  the 
establishment  of  the  PPP  cell,  will  strengthen  the  interface  between  the  public  and  private 
sectors.  
 
134.  Social  Impact.  The  beneficial social  impact  of  the  PGEIP  can  arise  from  the  following 
factors.  First  of  all,  the  introduction  of  more  efficient  public  resource  management  practices 
throughout  government  will  gradually  contribute  to  improvements  in  the  quality  of  service 

terms  of  output-oriented 

in 

 

 delivery, especially in key social sectors. Second, the improved pension system will strengthen 
the  social  safety  net.  Lastly,  the  improved  quality  of  life  through  higher  economic  and  income 
growth will have an overall and direct impact on social outcomes. The detailed poverty reduction 
and social strategy of the Program is in Appendix 13. 
 
135.  Resettlement,  Indigenous  People,  and  the  Environment.  The  PGEIP  will  cause  no 
direct  or  indirect  involuntary  resettlement,  and  will  not  lead  to  any  issues  affecting  indigenous 
peoples  (category  C).  The  PGEIP  is  also  unlikely  to  have  any  adverse  environmental  impact 
(category C). 
 
C. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

136.  The  realization  of  the  benefits  and  impact  of  the  PGEIP  depends  on  a  number  of 
assumptions  and  are  subject  to  a  variety  of  risks.  Mitigating  measures  have  accordingly  been 
integrated into the design of the Program. 
 
137.  Political  Risks.  Pakistan  is  in  an  election  year  and  any  political  changes  could  have 
major administrative consequences. The caretaker setup expected to be in place later in 2007 
may not have the appetite for long-gestation reforms. However, the risk of reversing the broad 
directions  of  reforms  is  low,  given  the  present  broad  consensus  on  reforms  among  the  major 
political  players.  The  flexibility  built  into  the  single-tranche  operations  is  also  well  suited  to 
addressing the uncertainty arising in this context, as specific reform actions can be adjusted to 
reflect changes in the political environment.  
 
138.  Governance  Risks. Reforms could be undermined or delayed by vested interests that 
are  threatened  by  greater  transparency  and  accountability.  However,  strong  ownership  and 
support  at  the  highest  political  and  bureaucratic  levels,  coupled  with  gradually  improving 
incentives for better performance, will help mitigate this risk. The PDF that began in 2003 has 
institutionalized broad-based stakeholder participation, and the PGEIP design has been defined 
through this participative process.  
 
139. 
Implementation  Risks.  Insufficient  capacity  within  the  GoPb  to  handle  the  envisaged 
reforms could impede implementation. However, with the help of the TA loan under the PRMP, 
and by adopting effective procurement options and hiring the Singapore Civil Service College, 
the  PMU  and  departments  have  been  able  to  overcome  capacity  limitations.  Enhancing  IA 
ownership of the Program is also a key method of mitigating implementation risks.  
 
140.  External  and  Macroeconomic  Risks.  Despite  uncertainty 
the  geopolitical 
environment,  the  external  environment  in  recent  years  has  been  largely  favorable  to  Pakistan 
and the country has had strong macroeconomic indicators in the past 5 years. However, while 
structural  reforms  are  beginning  to  show  positive  results,  poverty  levels  and  inequality  remain 
high and must be reduced. The widening trade imbalance and current account deficit, insecurity 
in  the  region,  and  the  cost  of  earthquake  reconstruction  accentuate  the  macroeconomic  risks. 
Some of the risks are beyond the control of the federal Government and the GoPb, but prudent 
economic  management  strategies  can  mitigate  macroeconomic  vulnerability.  Significant 
increases  in  the  expenditure  allocations  for  the  social  sectors  and  direct  poverty  reduction 
measures will lead to higher poverty reduction impact.

ACHIEVEMENTS OF RECENT REFORM PROGRAMS AND ANALYSIS OF CHALLENGES 
FACING PUNJAB 
 

Achievements  of  the  Punjab  in  the  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program  and 

I. 
Punjab Devolved Social Services Program  

1. 
Punjab  Resource  Management  Program.  Enhancing  the  effectiveness  of  public 
financial  management  in  the  Punjab  has  been  the  principal  objective  of  the  Punjab  Resource 
Management  Program  (PRMP).  Under  subprogram  (SP)  1  of  PRMP  (covering  reforms  over 
January 2003–June 2005), the government of the Punjab (GoPb) launched and implemented a 
range of key reform measures focused on fiscal restructuring to boost revenue generation and 
expenditure  rationalization,  and  private  sector  development.  Under  SP2  of  PRMP  (July  2005–
June 2007) the government carried forward the reforms focusing on (i) creating fiscal space, (ii) 
improving efficiency and transparency in the allocation and use of funds, (iii) increasing the pro-
poor impact of public spending and service delivery, and (iv) creating an enabling environment 
for private sector development. 
 
2. 
Creating fiscal space was a major objective of the PRMP. Measures to enhance revenue 
mobilization included the rationalization of the tax structure, and analytical work in preparation 
for  the  reorganization  of  the  Excise  and  Taxation  Department  to  increase  efficiency  in  tax 
collection.  Rationalization  of  expenditure  was  achieved  primarily  through  the  reduction  of 
interest  payments  by  swapping  high-interest  cash  development  loans  (CDLs)  from  the  federal 
Government  with  less-costly  borrowings  from  international  donors.  During  the  PRMP, 
$300 million  in  CDLs  was  retired  by  the  provincial  government.  The  introduction  of  a 
medium-term framework in fiscal planning and budgeting represents a key achievement under 
the  PRMP.  The  Finance  Department  (FD)  prepared  the  first  medium-term  budget  framework 
(MTBF)  in  fiscal  year  (FY)  2004,  which  included  3-year  annual  rolling  estimates  of  the  main 
categories of revenues and expenditures. The Planning and Development Department (P&DD) 
prepared a medium-term development framework (MTDF) for the first time in FY2006.   
 
3. 
Civil  service  reforms  under  the  PRMP  emphasized  capacity  building  of  civil  servants, 
especially through international exposure for senior public servants. A training relationship has 
been established with the Singapore Civil Service College. A civil service census of provincial 
government has been pilot-tested in one district government. A number of measures were also 
taken  to  facilitate  private  sector  development,  including  (i)  pilot-testing  of  public-private 
partnership models in the health sector, (ii) completion of an assessment of the provincial policy 
environment  and  cost  of  doing  business,  and  (iii)  strengthening  of  property  rights  though 
improved land titling.  
 
4. 
By taking a holistic approach to a wide range of reform areas, the PRMP has laid a firm 
basis  for  public  resource  management  reforms  in  the  Punjab.  Strengthening  public  resource 
management, however, is a complex and gradual process that requires long-term commitment. 
The  devolution  process  has  also  brought  about  new  challenges  that  require  realignment  of 
power and responsibilities between the provincial and local governments. Building on the reform 
outcomes  over  2003–2007,  the  GoPb  now  wishes  to  undertake  a  range  of  second-generation 
reforms to deal effectively with the challenges it faces. 
 
5. 
Achievements  of  Punjab  Devolved  Social  Services  Program.  Pakistan  introduced 
sweeping  devolution  reforms  in  2001.  A  key  objective  underpinning  devolution  is  improved 
social  service  delivery.  Poor  social  service  delivery,  and  the  resultant  lack  of  human 
development,  has  been  a  major  cause  of  poverty.  Devolution  was  intended  to  significantly 

 

  
40 
 

Appendix 2 

enhance service delivery by bringing service providers and governments closer to citizens than 
they had been under a centralized system. The loans for the Punjab Devolved Social Services 
Program  (PDSSP) 1 were  designed  within  this  broad  context.  The  program  was  approved  on 
20 December  2004,  and  the  first  tranche  was  released  on 26  December  2005.  The  release  of 
the second tranche is currently under consideration.  
 
6. 
PDSSP  is  a  multi-sector  and  multidimensional  governance  reform  program.  It  seeks  to 
strengthen  devolved  social  services  for  more  equitable,  efficient,  effective,  and  sustainable 
delivery  of  social  services  in  line  with  Punjab  Local  Government  Ordinance  (PLGO)  2001.  It 
addresses governance, financing, and technical constraints on devolved service delivery in the 
health,  education,  special  education,  and  water  supply  and  sanitation  sectors.  Reforms  under 
PDSSP seek three principal policy outcomes:  
 

(i) 
(ii) 
(iii) 

realigning intergovernmental relations to support devolved social services, 
rationalizing and setting minimum standards for social services, and  
strengthening  public  accountability  mechanisms  and  promoting  public-private 
partnerships.  

 
Various initiatives have been implemented under the PDSSP. Some key achievements 

7. 
to date are highlighted below. 
 
8. 
Articulating  and  Clarifying  Devolution.  Local  governments  initially  faced  huge 
problems  in  comprehending  devolution.  There  was  a  lack  of  understanding  about  devolved 
financial and administrative powers. To facilitate the working of devolution and local government, 
a  compendium  of  local  government  laws,  rules,  and  regulations  has  been  prepared  and 
published by PDSSP. The document has been circulated free of cost to all local governments. It 
has effectively helped explain devolution to provincial and local governments.  
 
Instituting  Planning.  Local  government  planning  capacity  was  practically  nonexistent 
9. 
before  the  implementation  of  the  PDSSP.  Under  the  PDSSP,  local  government  planning  has 
received  tremendous  impetus  from  the  annual  sector  planning  (ASP)  process.  Through 
intensive training, capacity building, and strong emphasis on ASP, the PDSSP has introduced 
guidelines for planning, initiated the annual planning process, and instituted planning practice at 
the local government level.  
 
10. 
In addition to ASP, the PDSSP also supported strategic planning over the medium term. 
The  medium-term  development  strategic  directions  for  the  four  social  sectors  covered  by  the 
PDSSP  have  found  fully  expression  in  the  development  of  the  MTDF.  The  MTDF  has  also 
become a key instrument for linking expenditure with improvements in service delivery. 
 
Bridging  Financing  Gaps  and  Introducing  Rules-Based  Resource  Allocation. The 
11. 
PDSSP introduced the concept of resource allocation to local governments through conditional 
grants. These have made possible timely and assured transfers of funds to local governments in 
a  transparent  manner,  helped  to  bridge  financing  gaps,  assisted  the  local  governments  in 
improving  social  service  delivery,  and  paved  the  way  for  introducing  transparent  rules-based 
resource allocation.

Addressing Human Resource Constraints. With the requirements of the PDSSP, the 
12. 
GoPb  has  filled  a  large  number  of  vacancies  in  the  four  social  sectors.  These  have  helped 
alleviate capacity constraints on service delivery. 
 
Introducing Service Delivery Standards. For the first time, service delivery standards 
13. 
have been introduced for social service delivery in the health, education, special education, and 
water  supply  and  sanitation  sectors  in  the  province.  The  development  and  enforcement  of 
technical and service standards are important instruments for improving the quality of services. 
The  standards  provide  benchmarks  for  regulators,  service  providers,  and  users.  Setting 
technical  and  service  standards  is  especially  important  in  the  post-devolution  era  as  the 
provincial  government  becomes  less  directly  involved  with  service  delivery,  while  assuming  a 
more important role as policy maker, regulator, and standard setter.  
 
14. 
Improving  Service  Delivery. On the important objective of improving service delivery, 
though only very limited data are currently available, there is tentative evidence to suggest that 
social  service  delivery  has  improved  since  devolution  in  2001.  For  example,  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB)-Department for International Development (DFID)-World Bank report 
Devolution in Pakistan (2004)2 notes that the efforts of the monitoring committee have resulted 
in improved attendance of staff working in social sectors. Furthermore, health sector employees 
are  now  more  likely  to  visit  health  facilities  than  before  devolution.  The  Social  Audit  of 
Governance  and  Delivery  of  Public  Services  of  the  Centro  de  Investigación  de  Enfermedades 
Tropicales 3  found  that  overall  satisfaction  with  government  health  facilities  increased  by  5 
percentage points in 2004 over the 2002 figure to reach 70%. More rigorous empirical analysis 
is  required  to  assess  the  impact  of  devolution  on  service  delivery  (footnote  2).  Supported  by 
ADB  TA  4504  under  PDSSP,  the  Punjab  is  undertaking  a  second  multiple-indicator  cluster 
survey. This will help generate the necessary data for assessing changes in service delivery.  
 
15. 
Strengthening  Monitoring.  The  development  of  service  standards  has  been  coupled 
with the development of systematic monitoring frameworks for provincial and local governments. 
These  measures  have  helped  improve  the  accountability  mechanisms  of  both  provincial  and 
local governments.  
 
Enhancing  Public-Private  Partnerships.  The  development  of  public-private 
16. 
partnerships (PPPs) has the potential to increase the pool of resources, mitigate risks through 
risk sharing, and enhance the efficiency of service delivery. In the Punjab, private participation 
in  the  health  and  education  sectors  has  become  increasingly  significant.  With  the  increased 
interest  in  PPPs,  the  province  urgently  needs  a  comprehensive  PPP  policy  and  regulatory 
framework  to  guide  PPP  practice.  The  PDSSP  supported  the  development  of  a  well-defined 
PPP  strategy.  This  has  also  gone  a  long  way  toward  institutionalizing  PPPs,  augmenting 
resources for public service delivery, and improving efficiency. 
 
17. 
Setting a Road Map for Devolution. The promulgation of PLGO 2001 and subordinate 
legislation since 2001 has enabled the devolution of administrative and financial powers to local 
governments. However, local governments still face problems in implementing these powers. It 
is  thus  critical  that  the  gaps  in  implementing  devolution  are  identified  and  plugged  to  enable 
local  governments  to  perform  their  functions  effectively.  The  mapping  and  development  of  an

II. 
 
A. 
 
20. 
Public resource management is the primary tool for a country’s economic management 
and public service delivery. Fiscal management and the quality of civil service are the two core 
elements of effective public resource management. Fiscal management consists of systems and 
procedures for medium-term planning and budgeting, as well as measures aimed at fiscal space 
creation  through  public  expenditure  management  and  revenue  generation  reform.  Public 
expenditure  management 
rationalization,  and 
prioritization measures. Expenditure compression is aimed at reducing nonproductive spending 
(e.g., interest payments), while expenditure rationalization and prioritization include streamlining 
the  current  expenditure  pattern  to  make  it  more  efficient  and  aligned  with  the  government’s 
development  priorities  (e.g.,  pension  reform,  salary  and  wage  reform,  and  divestment  of 
loss-making state-owned enterprises). Revenue-generation measures represent another tool for 
fiscal  space  creation.  They  consist  mainly  of  initiatives  to  increase  the  revenue  yield  of  taxes 
and fees raised by the government (e.g., tax policy and tax administration reform, and reform of 
user fees).  
 
21. 
The quality of the civil service is the second main pillar of public resource management, 
as it critically affects government’s efficiency and effectiveness in attaining its fiscal policy goals, 
and  ultimately  its  responsiveness  to  citizens’  needs.  A  well-functioning  civil  service  would 
enable  the  government  to  attract  and  retain  qualified  and  competent  staff  and  to  hold  them 
accountable for results while benefiting the citizens through improved public service delivery.  
 
22. 
Private sector development can also play a key role in enhancing the efficiency of public 
resource  management  by  improving  the  revenue-generating  capacity  and  enabling  a  more 
efficient allocation of resources across competing priorities. On the one hand, private sector–led 
growth would enlarge the tax base of the economy and increase the revenue yield. On the other 
hand, a dynamic and vibrant private sector would allow public sector disengagement from the 
provision of goods and services that do not justify public sector involvement. This would in turn 
create  fiscal  space  for  the  provision  of  public  service  services  and  government  spending  in 
pro-poor sectors.

Sector Background, Key Challenges, and Recent Achievements 

1. 

Medium-Term Planning and Budgeting 

A growing number of developing countries have adopted the medium-term expenditure 
23. 
framework (MTEF)4 to increase predictability in resource allocation, and to strengthen the links 
between policy, planning, and budgeting. Recent studies5 have highlighted the importance of a 
good  macro-fiscal  model  and  solid  budget  management  and  execution  practices  as  two  key 
enabling conditions for the successful implementation of MTEF.  
  
24.  Weak  Budget  Preparation  and  Execution  and  Poor  Performance  Orientation. 
Development expenditure is specifically related to investment in the development of physical or 
human  resources  through  defined  projects.  In  this  sense  it  must  be  distinguished  from  the 
accounting  distinction  between  current  and  capital  expenditure.  A  development  project  may 
involve both recurrent and capital elements.  
 
The recurrent budget refers to expenditures that are recurrent in nature and are further 
25. 
distinguished between regular and new expenditures. Budget submissions are made separately 
for the two expenditures, and priority in reviewing budget submissions is typically directed to the 
new  expenditure.  Regular  expenditure  is  increased  to  reflect  pay  and  price  increases  but  is 
assumed to be necessary and not subject to in-depth scrutiny. New expenditure may arise as a 
result  of  a  development  project  with  recurrent  expenditure  implications.  When  the  project  is 
completed  it  is  treated  as  new  expenditure  on  the  recurrent  budget  for  a  3-year  period  before 
being absorbed into the regular budget if its continuation is still justified.6  
 
26. 
The annual budget statement in its current format does not provide a transparent picture 
of  the  allocation  of  resources  across  sectors  and  spending  categories.  Expenditures  are  only 
aggregated  along  functional  classifications,  which  do  not  provide  information  about  the 
composition  of  expenditures  as  would  be  captured  from  the  economic  classification.  In  the 
annual  budget  statement  there  is  no  overall  summary  statement  giving  an  overview  of  the 
government budget in terms of surplus or deficit. 
 
On 1 November the budget call circular (BCC) is circulated to each department. It sets 
27. 
out  the  standard  forms  for  preparing  the  budget  proposals,  together  with  guidelines  for  their 
completion. The recurrent budget submissions are received and adjusted by the Budget Wing of 
the  FD. 7  There  are  no  formal  meetings  with  departments  to  negotiate  changes  in  the 
submissions,  though  informal  contact  may  be  made.  In  the  case  of  development  expenditure, 
the departmental submissions are examined in the P&DD. The BCC was updated in 2005/2006 
to  reflect  the  move  to  collect  data  for  the  MTBF,  and  included  nonfinancial  data  relating  to

30. 
Limited  Integration  between  Budgeting  and  Medium-Term  Planning.  The objective 
of  MTEF  is  to:  (i)  enforce  fiscal  discipline  through  the  control  of  aggregate  expenditures, 
(ii) support  the  strategic  allocation  of  resources  to  sectors,  and  (iii)  ensure  cost-effective 
implementation of programs and service delivery.  
 
31. 
The  implementation  of  MTEF  requires  interaction  among  the  central  departments  (FD 
and  P&DD),  the  line  departments,  and  the  local  governments.  Effective  MTEF  requires:    (i) 
sound  and  reliable  forecasts  of  resources  available  over  the  medium  term,    (ii)    a  transparent 
mechanism  for  determining  the  sectoral  allocation  of  resources,    (iii)  capacity  to  enforce  the 
sectoral  allocation  as  either  hard  or  soft  budget  ceilings,  (iv)  performance-based  budgeting 
relating the recurrent and development budgets to performance targets and indicators, and (v) a 
budget  data  recording  system,  which  captures  financial  and  nonfinancial  data  that  feed  into 
medium-term estimates of available resources.  

 

32. 
The MTBF contains sectoral expenditure allocations for the nondevelopment budget, but 
it is difficult to relate these allocations directly to the annual budget statement, as the manner of 
presentation is different and they are not currently used to provide departments with ceilings or 
guidelines for budget preparation.10

Performance-based  budgeting  (PBB)  allows  the  formulation  of  budget  estimates  in  line 
33. 
with  the  cost  of  the  resources  necessary  to  deliver  a  desired  standard  of  services.  The  dual 
budget process in the Punjab undermines the scope of PBB as its incremental approach makes 
it difficult to align the resource envelope with the service delivery goals. Likewise, the separation 
between  recurrent  and  development  budgets  hampers  a  comprehensive  assessment  of  the 
cross-budgetary implications of the activities underlying public service delivery.  
 
34. 
Low  Value  for  Money  in  Public  Service  Delivery.  The  devolution  process  has 
increased  the  responsibility  of  local  governments  in  the  delivery  of  essential  public  services: 
health  care  and  education  are  the  primary  responsibility  of  district  governments,  while  water 
supply and sanitation are the responsibility of the tehsil municipal administrations (TMAs) 11  and 
the union councils.  
 
35. 
The  capacity  of  local  governments  to  allocate  scarce  resources  in  line  with  the 
development  priorities  is  weak.  Under  the  devolved  system,  the  zila  nazim  (elected  district 
representative) enjoys relative autonomy in the definition of budget allocation and the budget is 
subject  solely  to  approval  from  the  district  council.  To  date,  though  district  governments  are 
responsible for the delivery of basic education and health services, their budget estimates are 
not  based  on  desired  standards  of  services.  A  system  for  assessing  the  cost  of  providing 
services is currently not in place, and this further exacerbates the disconnect between allocated 
resources and the funds needed to meet their service delivery obligations. 
 
36.

However,  the  ultimate  purpose  of  the  MTBF  exercise  has  been  undermined  by  the  fact  that  it 
has not been updated yearly, and thus does not provide a realistic assessment of the resources 
available over the medium term. A new MTBF for FY2008 to FY2010 has been approved by the 
FD. An MTBF cell tasked with producing the MTBF has also been created within the FD. This 
cell is still not fully staffed, however, and terms of reference and job descriptions have not been 
prepared.   
 
37. 
The first MTDF was published in FY2006. Unlike the MTBF, the MTDF is updated yearly 
and the published MTDF documentation provides an overview of the sectoral visions, strategies, 
and  key  targets  for  the  period.  An  MTDF  cell  has  also  been  established  in  the  P&DD  to 
formulate the MTDF, monitor its execution, and coordinate with other divisions in P&DD. In this 
case as well, however, operationalization of the MTDF cell has been very limited.  
 
Since  FY2006,  sector  departments  have  been  requested  to  submit  details  of  the

performance  targets  to  be  achieved  through  the  execution  of  Annual  Development  Program. 
These targets are anchored in the MDGs, though it is not clear to what extent they are costed, 
and hence whether they are linked to development expenditure estimates.

2. 

Civil Service Pension System 

 

43. 
The GoPb is the largest employer in Pakistan, with about one million civil servants and 
about 388,000 pensioners (including retired employees, and spouses and eligible dependents of 
deceased  employees).  The  pension  system  rests  on  two  main  pillars:  the  Punjab  pension 
system  (PPS)  and  the  General  Provident  Fund  (GPF).  Membership  in  both  schemes  is 
mandatory. Since 2005, most civil servants have been hired on a contractual basis and are not 
entitled to PPS and GPF benefits, receiving instead a 30% salary premium. About 50,000 civil 
servants have been contractual employees since 2005.  
 
44. 
The PPS is a noncontributory, unfunded defined-benefits system financed from current 
government  revenues.  The  normal  retirement  age  is  60,  subject  to  the  employee’s  having 
completed 10 years of service. Individual benefit levels are determined by a formula that takes 
into account the final wage and the length of service. The replacement rate is capped at 70% (of 
the basic wage in the final year) for a worker with 30 years of service. Up to 35% of the pension 
can be commuted and taken as a lump sum, and the remainder is paid as an annuity until death. 
 
45. 
The  GPF  is  an  employee-only  contributory  scheme.  Civil  servants  are  required  to 
contribute  3–8%  of  basic  salary  to  the  GPF,  and  the  contributions  are  notionally  housed  in 
individual accounts. Aside from book entry, employee contributions are not kept separately, and 
are included in the provincial government’s consolidated accounts. Accumulated funds are not 
invested  to  meet  pension  obligations,  which  like  the  liabilities  under  the  PPS,  are  financed 
through the general budget. The government determines the rate of return on employees’ GPF 
contributions each year, which is currently around 11%. Workers can borrow from their accounts 
up to age 50 for specific purposes such as illness and related travel, overseas travel related to a 
dependent’s  education,  marriages  and  funerals,  and  purchase  of  land,  house,  and  vehicles. 
After age 50, members can borrow up to 60% of the balance without having to give a reason or 
pay  back  the  advance.  After  age  55,  an  advance  of  up  to  80%  of  the  balance  can  be  made, 
again with no need to repay the advance. Any remaining balance can be taken as a lump sum 
at the age of 60 or a year before retirement. 

 

 

       

Appendix 2     

47

 

 

Two other benefit schemes are available to the employees of the GoPb: the Benevolent 
46. 
Fund (BF) and the Central Employees Insurance Fund (CEIF). The BF covers all civil servants 
except the police and the Population Welfare Department. Civil servants contribute 2% of their 
basic pay, and receive a range of benefits such as a monthly payment to dependents on death 
in service, marriage benefits, funeral grants, and education scholarships. The deductions for the 
CEIF are paid as premiums to State Life Insurance, and provide a death benefit.  
 
47. 
Unfunded  Pension  System.  As  highlighted  above,  both  the  PPS  and  the  GPF  are 
unfunded  schemes  financed  through  the  provincial  budget.  Preliminary  estimates  indicate  that 
the  government’s  pension  liabilities  could  be  as  high  as  PRs400  billion.  The  outstanding  GPF 
balance,  including  contributions  and  interest  credited,  is  reported  at  PRs17  billion.  Pension 
outlays  have  escalated  in  recent  years,  and  increased  from  PRs1.7  billion  in  FY1991  to 
PRs12.6 billion in FY2006. Interest payments on GPF balances have likewise increased sharply 
and  amounted  to  PRs4.5  billion  in  FY2006.  GPF  interest  payments  currently  exceed 
contribution, and the net outflow is projected to rise in the coming years. 
 
The  GoPb  recognizes  that  its  pension  obligations  have  important  implications  for  the 
48. 
finances  of  the  province,  and  that  pension  expenditures,  if  unchecked,  could  crowd  out 
investment  in  the  infrastructure  and  social  sectors.  Urgent  reforms  are  therefore  needed  to 
ensure  the  financial  sustainability  of  the  pension  system,  and  to  create  the  fiscal  space  for 
priority development expenditures.

payroll 
functions,  the  Office  of  the  Accountant  General,  Punjab  (AGP)  records  civil  servants’ 
employment data, including name, identification number, date of employment, wage history, and, 
as  applicable,  the  date  of  retirement,  termination  of  employment,  or  death.  At  retirement,  the 
worker makes an application with the Office of the AGP, which calculates the worker’s benefits 
and  creates  a  payment  booklet.  To  collect  the  monthly  benefit  the  pensioner  (or  dependent) 
must present the payment booklet to a designated payment agent at a branch of the National 
Bank of Pakistan (NBP).  
 
50. 
An effective pension system requires: (i) a system for accurately recording employment 
history and employee contribution, and calculating benefits; and (ii) a system for ensuring timely 
payment of benefits to pensioners. The calculation of pension benefits is based on the length of 
service and final salaries. The calculation of GPF balances is relatively more complex, requiring 
information on (i) deductions of monthly contributions from payroll based on grades, (ii) crediting 
of  yearly  interest  on  the  balances,  and  (iii)  advances  against  balances  and  repayment  of 
advances.  The  system  of  record-keeping  and  benefit  calculations  in  the  Punjab  is  largely 
manual  and  paper-based.  The  absence  of  a  robust  record-keeping  and  management 
information  system,  combined  with  weak  accounting  and  actuarial  analysis  capacity,  has 
resulted  in  problems  regarding  the  accuracy  of  pension  entitlement  calculation  and  individual 
payments. Cases of missing contributions, and therefore missing investment returns on the GPF, 
are common. There is no formal mechanism for a pensioner to initiate an inquiry or an appeals 
process when such omissions occur.  
 
51. 
Pension  disbursement  through  a  designated  branch  of  NBP  is  costly  because  of  the 
cumbersome identification and entitlement verification processes. The payment agent identifies 
the retiree through the latter’s identification card and payment booklet, makes the payment, and 
records  the  payment  in  the  payment  booklet  and  on  the  form  obtained  from  the  Office  of  the 
AGP.  A  copy  of  the  form  is  retained  by  the  payment  agent  and  another  copy  is  routed  to  the 
Office  of  the  AGP.  The  present  system  generates  a  payment  notice  to  the  authorized  NBP 

its 

 

  
48 
 

Appendix 2 

branch  for  each  transaction  and  does  not  include  monthly  authorized  allocations.  This 
arrangement  not  only  further  increases  the  cost  of  pension  disbursement,  but  also  makes  the 
system  more  error-prone.  Moreover,  there  is  no  mechanism  for  triggering  an  action  when 
questionable  transactions  occur.  Thus  leakages  from  the  system,  in  the  form  of  “ghost 
pensioners,” are results in significant and entail considerable cost to the taxpayer. The system 
of pension payments is weaker in rural areas because of the lack of adequate staff resources in 
bank branches.  
 
52.  Weak  Benefit  Structure.  Certain  features  of  the  current  pension  scheme  have  led  to 
inequitable and arbitrary outcomes at the individual level. For instance, the last pay drawn for an 
employee is used as the basis for calculating the pension. This can favor those who get a pay 
raise  or  a  promotion  immediately  before  retirement.  The  international  best  practice  is  to  use 
average earnings over several years as the basis. Increases in pension benefits, to compensate 
for changes in the cost of living, are made ad hoc, and often trail inflation. Interest payments on 
GPF contributions are likewise ad hoc and unpredictable. Currently, up to 35% of the pension 
can be commuted and taken as a lump sum, with the remainder paid as an annuity until death. 
The commutation allowance is high by international standards, and may not be consistent with 
the public policy objective of facilitating consumption-smoothing and ensuring adequate old-age 
income for civil servants. 
 
Those who joined the civil service after 2004 are employed on a contractual basis and 
53. 
do not receive pension and GPF benefits. Over 50,000 employees thus far are affected by this 
arrangement. There are now growing concerns regarding workplace morale, and the social and 
political  implications  of  having  a  significant  proportion  of  civil  servants  with  little  or  no  savings 
and no pension benefits.  
 
54. 
The  pension  rules  were  established  in  the  1960s,  and  the  GPF  rules  in  the  1970s. 
Though  certain  modifications  have  been  introduced  since,  there  is  an  urgent  need  for  a 
comprehensive  review  of  the  two  schemes  to  assess  their  continued  relevance  in  the  current 
socioeconomic context. 
 
Recent  Achievements.  As  the  first  step  toward  a  funded  scheme,  the  GoPb 
55. 
promulgated  the  Punjab  Pension  Fund  (PPF)  Act  in  March  2006.  The  PPF  Act  provides  the 
legal basis for the establishment of a corporate body with the objective of generating resources 
through  fund  investment  to  discharge  the  pension  liability  of  the  province.  The  General 
Provident  Investment  Fund  (GPIF)  Act  has  been  submitted  to  the  provincial  assembly.  The 
objective  of  the  GPIF  is  to  generate  investment  returns  for  the  payment  of  benefits  under  the 
GPF  pillar.  Implementing  Rules—specifying  fiduciary  requirements,  exposure  limits  and  risk 
management, accounting and auditing, internal controls, and compliance—for both the PPF Act 
and the draft GPIF Act have been adopted. 
 
56. 
To  date,  the  GoPb  has  earmarked  PRs8  billion  for  the  capitalization  of  the  PPF  and 
PRs4  billion  for  the  GPIF.  The  GoPb  is  committed  to  allocating  budget  resources  to  reach  a 
minimum  capitalization  of  PRs100  billion  by  FY2015/2016,  and  has  recently  completed  an 
actuarial valuation, and adopted a funding strategy for PPF and GPIF.   
 
57. 
Steps  toward  starting  investment  operations  have  also  been  initiated.  Management 
committee  members,  including  private  sector  representatives,  have  been  appointed,  and  the 
selection of the managing director is under way.

3. 

Civil Service Reform 

58. 
The  public  sector  employs  about  11%  of  employed  workers  in  Punjab.  This  number 
includes about 967,000 in sanctioned posts in government departments and more than 100,000 
employees  in  the  123  public  sector  autonomous  bodies.  While  the  share  is  moderate,  it 
understates  the  importance  of  the  public  sector  as  a  major  formal  sector  employer,  given  that 
self-employment  accounts  for  about  60%  of  total  employment.  The  civil  service  wage  bill  and 
pensions account for about 59% of total consolidated recurrent expenditure. The need to reform 
the  civil  service  has  been  felt  both  at  the  national  and  the  provincial  levels.  Despite  various 
attempts,  the  common  perception  is  that  the  system  remains  similar  to  that  inherited  from 
Pakistan’s  colonial  past.  A  recent  survey  by  Pakistan  Institute  of  Development  Economics 
indicates widespread negative perception and general discontent about public services, on the 
one  hand,  and  disillusionment  of  civil  servants  themselves,  on  the  other.  Some  of  the  main 
issues in the Punjab context are discussed below. 
 
59.  Weak  Recruitment,  Performance  Evaluation,  and  Promotion.  An  effective 
recruitment system is essential for ensuring the quality of entry of civil servants. In the Punjab, 
the recruitment of public servants for basic pay scale (BPS) 1712 and above is carried out by the 
Punjab  Public  Service  Commission  (PPSC).  It  is  widely  acknowledged  that  the  commission 
faces  challenges  because  of  structural,  capacity,  and  procedural  constraints.  Similarly, 
performance evaluation has not served as an effective tool for performance monitoring. A large 
proportion of civil servants do not have job descriptions, let alone targets for achievement. The 
existing annual confidential report is commonly regarded as a compliance task and not useful as 
a  record  of  performance  evaluation.  Further,  in  a  system  in  which  promotions  are  essentially 
based  on  seniority,  performance  evaluations  play  a  limited  role  in  career  progression.  The 
present cadre system also places more weight on recruiting senior management from the elite 
groups  and  not  enough  on  seeking  out  management  talent  from  specialist  groups  or  from 
outside the civil service.  
 
60. 
Uncompetitive  Compensation  and  Benefits.  There  is  substantial  evidence  that  the 
real  compensation  gap  between  public  and  private  salaries  and  emoluments  has  steadily 
increased.  Moreover,  the  compensation  structure  of  wages  is  not  closely  linked  with 
performance  and  does  not  provide  adequate  incentives  for  good  performance.  The  provincial 
government  has  no  control  over  civil  service  salary  scales,  which  are  set  by  the  federal 
Government.  It  can,  however,  create  contract  positions  outside  the  cadre  scales  or  pay 
additional  allowances  for  specific  positions.  For  example,  program  management  units  (PMUs) 
have been used as a device to create specific positions attracting higher reward. There is some 
evidence suggesting that the recruitment and remuneration practice of PMUs has strengthened 
performance  incentives.  PMUs  thus  should  be  seen  as  a  testing  case  and  precursor  for 
introducing performance-based human resource management in the civil service of the province. 
 
61. 
Gaps in Contract Employment Policy. Civil services reforms are a challenging task for 
any  government.  Despite  this,  the  GoPb  has  implemented  some  important  measures.  One 
major  reform  initiative  since  2003  has  been  the  shift  toward  contractual  employment  for  new 
entrants  into  government  service.  Employees  recruited  on  a  contractual  basis  are  paid  an 
additional 30% of the minimum salary of the relevant pay scale as compensation for not being 
eligible  for  a  pension.  However,  the  difference  between  the  compensation  of  regular  and

contract  employees  is  not  large  enough  to  discourage  employees  from  seeking  conversion  to 
regular  mode.  The  pressure  to  convert  is  building  up  as  the  number  of  contract  employees 
increases.  
 
Frequent  Transfers.  There  are  no  systematic  policies  or  mechanisms  for  placements 
62. 
and transfers. In many cases, the process of placements and transfers lacks a professional and 
technical basis, leading to a mismatch between skills and placement. Transfers are often made 
within  a  year  of  service,  rather  than  the  recommended  minimum  of  2–3  years.  As  such,  the 
incumbents often barely have time to settle into a new job before they are moved on. 
 
63.  Weak  Technical  and  Managerial  Skills.  A  World  Bank  report 13 points  out  that  the 
technical competence of civil servants has been declining over the past two decades. There is 
also  limited  interest  in  the  training  of  civil  servants  because  of  the  low  returns  from  training. 
There have been increased efforts in the training area by the GoPb in recent years. Supported 
by the PRMP, the government entered into a short-term arrangement with the Singapore Civil 
Service  College  to  undertake  various  training  programs.  These  efforts  mark  an  encouraging 
step  toward  improving  the  capacity  of  civil  servants.  However,  much  remains  to  be  done  to 
upgrade capacity, incentives, and accountability in the system. 
 
64. 
Challenges  Posed  by  Devolution.  The  PLGO  2001  has  significantly  changed 
intergovernmental relationships. Given the relatively short period since the launch of devolution, 
there  is  continuing  confusion  over  the  roles,  functions,  and  mandates  to  be  performed  by 
different levels of government and the mechanisms for coordination between departments and 
agencies.  Lack  of  capacity  at  the  local  government  level  for  key  functions  such  as  planning, 
budgeting,  and  human  resource  management  also  create  a  major  constraint  on  the  effective 
functioning of this level of government.  
 
65. 
Recent  Achievements.  Despite  significant  challenges,  the  GoPb  has  demonstrated 
strong commitment to push forward civil service reforms with the objective of fostering a more 
efficient,  effective,  and  responsive  government.  To  steer  the  reform  process,  Change 
Management  Unit  (CMU)  was  recently  been  upgraded  into  the  Public  Policy  and  Change 
Management Wing (PPCMW) of the Services and General Administration Department (S&GAD), 
under the stewardship and oversight of the chief secretary. The Rules of Business have been 
amended  and  some  of  the  functions  of  the  Organization  and  Methods  Department  were 
transferred to the PPCMW to enable it to satisfy its mandate.  
 
66.  With  the  support  of  ADB,  efforts  are  under  way  to  recruit  experts  to  develop  a  human 
resource  management  (HRM)  manual  and  design  a  pilot  performance-based  human  resource 
management scheme for selected departments/agencies and positions. 

 
The  GoPb  desires  to  further  strengthen  its  training  capability  to  upgrade  the  skills  of 
67. 
provincial  employees.  It  has  therefore  decided  to  adopt  a  three-pronged  strategy  for  the 
professional  development  of  its  staff.  First,  it  is  negotiating  a  long-term  arrangement  with 
Singapore Civil Service College to build the capacity and competence of the Management and 
Professional  Development  Department  (MPDD)  trainers  and  resource  persons  to  meet  future 
training  needs.  Second,  it  is  planning  to  supplement  training  resource  capabilities  by 
outsourcing some of this activity and has entered into an agreement with the Lahore University

4. 

Private Sector Development 

68. 
Private sector development is essential for the province to ensure job creation, economic 
development,  and  poverty  reduction.  The  private  sector  in  the  Punjab  is  dominated  by 
small-scale  informal  enterprises  operating  primarily  in  the  services  and  manufacturing  sector: 
97%  of  manufacturing  units  employ  fewer  than  10  people.  Today,  the  small-  and  medium 
enterprise (SME) sector contributes 30% of national gross domestic product (GDP) and 35% of 
national  value  added  to  the  industrial  sector  and  generates  25%  of  manufacturing  export 
earnings.14 There  are  a  number  of  impediments  to  the  development  of  the  SME  sector.  Most 
notable is the lack of access to financial resources, poorly developed property rights, low levels 
of  human  resource  capacity,  weak  regulatory  oversight,  expensive  but  poor  quality  of  public 
utilities, and weak marketing and transport linkages.  
 
69. 
The labor force in 2002 numbered an estimated 27 million, 8.5% of these unemployed. 
The population of the Punjab is growing rapidly (3%), and the labor force is growing at a faster 
rate than the annual growth rate of new jobs registered (2.7%). The need to create new jobs, as 
a  large  number  of  young  people  enter  the  labor  force,  cannot  be  overestimated.  While  the 
agricultural  sector  will  continue  to  provide  the  bulk  of  employment  opportunities  for  the 
population, it is debatable whether it can provide full employment to substantial new additional 
labor. The bulk of employment opportunities have to be generated by the nonfarm sector.   
 
70. 
Lack  of  Coherent  Private  Sector  Development  Strategy.  The  Punjab needs a good 
strategic framework to define the role of the state vis-à-vis the private sector. Although almost 
9 out of 10 Punjabis are already employed in the private sector, the reach of that sector in terms 
of contribution to provincial economy is only about 30%. The private sector requires support in 
addressing issues that have a public good element, impose positive or negative externalities on 
other businesses or the society, or have collective action issues. The state can help in this area 
by adopting a coherent private sector development (PSD) strategy and underwriting costs, and 
encouraging the development of collective solutions.  
 
71. 
High  Cost  of  Doing  Business.  In  all  recent  surveys,  the  regulatory  and  compliance 
burdens for businesses in the Punjab still figure as major concerns. Financial and fiscal sector 
reforms have gone some way to reducing the cost of doing business. However, setting up the 
“rules of the game” and the regulatory framework remains the responsibility of the government, 
and reforms in this area need to be tackled urgently. To facilitate long-term engagement on this 
issue,  the  Punjab  Government  Efficiency  Improvement  Program  (PGEIP)  foresees  the  GoPb 
instituting a regular survey on the cost of doing business in the province. The survey will (i) set 
benchmarks  for  performance,  (ii)  allow  tracking  of  costs  and  of  progress  made,  and  (iii)  allow 
regular and continuous engagement with the issues. It will identify the key problem areas and 
the government will introduce measures to implement the legal and institutional reforms needed

to bring down the cost of doing business. This will be crucial in attracting increasing investments, 
both foreign and local, into the Punjab.  
 
72. 
In  addition  to  the  cost-of-business  survey,  a  number  of  actions  can  be  taken  to 
strengthen the regulatory framework, including: (i) a strategy of effectively promoting core labor, 
environment,  and  other  quality  standards;  (ii)  the  conduct  of  a  regulatory  impact  assessment, 
institutionalized  in  selected  departments;  and  (iii)  the  establishment  of  an  alternative  dispute 
resolution facility in Lahore. 
 
73. 
Public-Private Partnerships. Private sector participation in the social sectors is already 
rapidly increasing in Pakistan. For example, the latest estimates show that some 30–35% of all 
school-going  children  now  attend  private  schools.  Yet,  there  are  segments  of  society  that  the 
for-profit  private  sector will  not serve,  as  these segments  do  not  afford  enough  returns  for  the 
private  sector.  In  addition,  there  are  areas  in  which  public  good  elements  of  services  are  so 
strong that for-profit private sector participation does not make economic sense (public health, 
preventive health, quality of education).  
 
74. 
Absence  of  PPP  Framework.  There  are  sectors  providing  services  to  the  Punjab 
economy which for historical, legal, or economic reasons have been primarily the responsibility 
of  the  public  sector.  Yet  within  these  sectors  the  public  sector  feels  that  it  cannot  deliver  the 
requisite quality and quantity of services required to meet the demands of the people. Primarily, 
the  government  does  not  have  enough  resources  (human,  financial  and  technical)  to  cater  to 
large infrastructure or service delivery needs.  PPPs can be one way  of  reducing the  demand-
supply gap. The Punjab lacks a policy or regulatory framework and the institutional capacity for 
effectively promoting PPPs.  
 
75. 
Recent  Achievements.  The private sector has benefited from recent reforms including 
consolidation, rationalization, and rate adjustment for provincial taxes (reducing the number of 
taxes, improving payment processes, reducing compliance costs and the possibility of leakages); 
some rationalization in labor-related levies and inspections; changes in some archaic laws (for 
example, regarding boiler inspections); reduction in bias against commercialization of property 
(some  rationalization  in  stamp  duties  and  other  charges);  improvements  in  building  codes; 
reduction  in  bias  against  rental  property  (as  opposed  to  owner-occupied  property);  and 
facilitation  of  private  sector  involvement  in  agricultural  marketing  (procurement,  storage, 
processing, and trade).

A. 

Second-Generation Reforms and Program Structure  

In  conjunction  with  the  implementation  of  the  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program 
1. 
(PRMP)  and  the  Punjab  Devolved  Social  Services  Program  (PDSSP),  the  government  of  the

federal  Government  related  to  the  Access  to  Justice  Program  (AJP)  and  Decentralization 
Support  Program  reforms  (paras.  9–11  of  main  text).  Supported  by  these  programs,  the

Having accomplished some key milestones, it now wishes to move on to a second generation of 
reforms, which will form important building blocks in the medium term toward achieving Vision 
2020 (para. 6 of main text).  
 
2.

supported. Building on this, the PMDGP will support the implementation of the strategies toward 
meeting  health-related  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  Likewise,  the  PGEIP  will 
support  the  development  of  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  PPP,  which  will  in  turn 
facilitate  private  sector  participation  in  the  provision  of  social  and  infrastructure  services. 
Furthermore, a well-functioning judiciary, which ensures enforceability of contracts and security 
of property rights—key outcomes envisioned under the PAJP—will enhance investor confidence, 
thereby contributing to private sector development. 
 
4. 
Program Clusters with Single Tranches. The framework would build on lessons learnt 
from  PRMP  and  take  into  account  reforms  carried  out  by  the  GoPb  over  the  past  few  years. 
First,  it  brings  together  public  sector,  MDG-related,  and  judicial  sector  reforms  in  integrated 
clusters  of  programs  to  ensure  fullest  coordination.  Second,  the  GoPb  and  ADB  have 
established a strong partnership through the implementation of the PRMP. This has laid a solid 
foundation for a mature relationship, serving as a platform for constructive policy dialogue. The 
government  has  demonstrated  strong  commitment  to  reforms.  The  policy  conditions  could 
therefore serve more as a tool to guide reforms rather than as rigid prescriptive actions. Third, 
experience  has  shown 
learning  by  doing  and 
experimentation.  The  program  cluster  approach,  comprising  a  series  of  single-tranche 
operations,  offers  a  more  productive  means  of  responding  to  changing  domestic  and  external 
circumstances,  and  reflecting  learning  in  moving  forward  into  complex  areas  such  as  civil 
service  reforms  and  performance-based  resource  allocation.  With  greater  focus  on  eventual 
outcomes  or  essential  intermediate  steps,  the  cluster  approach  ensures  smoother  program 
implementation,  as  has  been  shown  in  ADB’s  recent  experience  in  Indonesia  and  the 
Philippines  and  in  the  World  Bank’s  development  policy  loan  modality.  In  such  areas,  where 
reforms  need  at  least  5–6  years  to  take  firm  root,  prescribing  all  actions  up  front  is  neither 
desirable nor feasible.1  
 
Greater  Involvement  of  Stakeholders  as  well  as  ADB.  The  integrated  framework 
5. 
would enable continuous feedback from all relevant stakeholders in Pakistan. At the same time, 
the  single-tranche  structure  with  indicative  outcome-oriented  actions  will  enable  ADB’s 
Management and Board to provide more effective guidance on essential public sector reforms 
that have been pursued successfully elsewhere, without adopting a rigid prescriptive stance up 
front.

ASSESSMENT OF PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY 
IN THE PUNJAB  

1. 
The  public  financial  management  and  accountability  (PFMA)  assessment  completed  in 
March  2007  used  an  indicator-led  analysis  based  on  the  approved  Public  Expenditure  and 
Financial Accountability (PEFA) framework, which covers 31 indicators across seven core areas, 
namely:  (i)  budget  credibility;  (ii)  transparency  and  comprehensiveness;  (iii)  policy-based 
budgeting;  (iv)  predictability  and  control  in  budget  execution;  (v)  accounting,  recording,  and 
reporting; (vi) external scrutiny and audit; and (vii) donor practices.  
 
2. 
The public financial management performance was assessed against each indicator and 
ratings from “A” to “D” assigned on the basis of criteria defined by the PEFA framework. A rating 
of “A” indicates international-level practice and “B” good performance, while ratings of “C” and 
“D”  point  to  the  need  for  improvement.  The  table  below  shows  how  the  government  of  the 
Punjab (GoPb) performed against each indicator.

the  PFM  system  is  able  to  deliver  fiscal  discipline  and  is  responsive  to  changes  in
