to keep track of the government’s payment arrears.  
 
The transparency and comprehensiveness of the budget system conform to international 
4. 
standards 
financial 
statistics/classification  of  the  functions  of  the  government  standards,  and  includes  the  most

5. 
The  overall  budget  cycle  was  assessed  according  to  the  four  subcategories  of 
(i) policy-based budgeting (nos. 11–15); (ii) predictability and control in budget execution (nos. 
16–21);  (iii) accounting,  recording,  and  reporting  (nos.  22–25);  and  (iv)  external  scrutiny  and 
audit (nos. 26–28).  
 
6. 
The budget preparation process in the GoPb is clear with adequate timelines, while good 
progress  has  been  made  in  introducing  budget  planning  with  a  medium-term  perspective. 
Reform initiatives have also been introduced in tax administration and tax policy, though scope 
for  improvement  still  exists  with  respect  to  the  determination  of  tax  liabilities,  taxpayers’ 
registration,  and  effective  tax  collection.  Major  areas  of  improvement  in  budget  control  and 
execution  concern  the  effectiveness  of  payroll  controls,  the  overall  quality  of  the  procurement 
process  (e.g.,  use  of  open  competition  for  award  of  contracts  and  existence  of  procurement 
complaints  mechanism),  and  the  system  of  internal  audit,  whose  quality  is  very  poor.  Budget 
accounting  and  reporting  is  satisfactory  in  account  reconciliation,  the  reporting  of  information 
from line departments to central departments, and the quality of midyear budget reports. Finally, 
external audit is very weak in the timely submission of audit reports to the legislature, follow-up 
of audit recommendations, and legislative scrutiny over budget execution.  
 
7. 
Donors’ support practices were rated favorably with regard to the predictability of funds 
for  budget  support,  reporting  on  project/program  disbursements,  and  procedures  for  the 
management of funds, which follow national procedures.

Box A5: The Department for International Development–Assisted 
Punjab Resource Management Program 

  
 
 
  
The  Department  for  International  Development  (DFID)  of  the  United  Kingdom  is  supporting  the  government  of  the 
Punjab  in  the  implementation  of  the  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program  (PRMP)  and  has  provided  technical 
assistance  (TA)  of  £5  million  to  be  disbursed  over  a  3-year  period  until  2009.  This  support  phase  is  ongoing  and  is 
focused  on  key  PRMP  intervention  areas—public  financial  management,  civil  service  reforms,  and  private  sector 
development. Additional areas of support include reforming and building the capacity of the Bureau of Statistics (BOS) 
and  the  Punjab  Economic  Research  Institute.  An  amount  of  £2  million  has  also  been  earmarked  for  the  Policy 
Development  Fund,  to  be  used  in  response  to  requests  from  the  government  of  the  Punjab  as  the  assistance  unfolds 
and needs are identified. Coordination with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) TA for the PRMP is ensured through the 
executive and steering committees of the PRMP.  

The  Government  of  Pakistan  and  the  Government  of  the  United  Kingdom  also  signed  recently  a  10-year  partnership 
agreement, whose purpose is to afford better predictability in development assistance and better alignment on key policy 
themes. The initial phase (until 2011) comprises a grant assistance package of £480 million, which is expected to take 
effect in April 2008. A substantial part of this assistance is meant for the province of Punjab. An initial assistance of £30 
million is being designed in collaboration with the Punjab to assist the 15 poorer districts in the province. The focus of 
assistance will be on alleviating poverty and improving social service delivery. On the back of the long-term partnership, 
the DFID is now working on evolving a more focused 10-year partnership with the government of the Punjab. The details 
of the partnership are yet to be finalized. The coordination between ADB and DFID under PRMP is a key to ensuring aid 
effectiveness.  

DFID Support for PRMP and PGEIP 

DFID is providing a parallel TA, amounting to £5 million, from 2006 to 2009 to support governance and public resource 
management reforms in the Punjab. The overall goal of the DFID assistance is to help the government move toward an 
accountable,  efficient,  and  effective  government  that  meets  the  needs  of  its  people.  Specifically,  the  following  outputs 
are  expected:  (i)  improved  availability  and  quality  of  data,  and  economic  and  social  research  on  the  Punjab;  (ii)  more 
transparent  and  results-based  budget  allocations;  (iii)  public  administrative  reform,  fully  consistent  with  Punjab  Local 
Government  Ordinance  (PLGO)  2001,  and  cognizant  of  the  current  and  future  human  resource  needs  of  the 
government;  (iv)  improved  policies  and  capacity  to  support  private  sector  development;  (v)  improved  ability  of  the 
government of the Punjab to develop policy in areas complementary to the Punjab Government Efficiency Improvement 
Program (PGEIP); and (vi) a communication strategy in place to widen ownership of pro-poor reforms. 

The  TA  grant  is  allocated  as  follows:  Board  of  Statistics  and  Punjab  Economic  Research  Institute,  £1.3  million;  public 
financial  management,  £0.5  million;  private  sector  development,  £0.5  million;  civil  service  reforms,  £0.5  million;  and 
communication  strategy,  £0.2  million.  In  addition,  a  Policy  Development  Support  Fund  of  £2  million  can  be  used  to 
respond  to  requests  from  the  government  for  help  in  developing  policy  in  important  areas  related  to  public  financial 
management that were not covered by the previous PRMP. 

While  the  ADB  TA/program  and  the  DFID  grant  share  some  broad  common  areas,  including  public  financial 
management, civil service reforms, and private sector development, the possibility of overlap and duplication is small for 
a number of reasons. First, while the total DFID TA grant is £5 million, the allocation to the three common areas is only 
£1.5 million. Second, there are numerous issues in all the three common areas and the TA needs are large, reducing the 
possibility  of  duplication.  Third,  both  ADB  and  DFID  are  committed  to  achieving  donor  coordination  and  aid 
effectiveness. Thus, ADB and DFID will actively coordinate with each other to achieve complementarity of TA activities 
and  outputs.  For  example,  in  the  civil  service  area,  DFID’s  major  area  of  assistance  will  be  in  developing  a  human 
resource management information database. Fourth and most importantly, the Planning and Development Department 
(P&DD)  is  the  executing  agency  for  both  ADB  and  the  DFID  assistance,  and  the  PRMP  program  management  unit 
(PMU)  is  the  overall  program/TA  management  unit.  The  DFID  TA  will  be  implemented  by  a  DFID-appointed  TA 
management  agency  (TAMA),  which  will  work  with  the  government  of  the  Punjab.  The  PRMP  PMU  will  closely 
coordinate  with  the  TAMA  to  ensure  that  the  synergies  between  PGEIP  and  the  DFID  TA  are  maximized.  Regular 
interaction between ADB, DFID, and the government will be maintained to improve coordination.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE LOAN:  
CAPACITY BUILDING FOR PUNJAB GOVERNMENT EFFICIENCY IMPROVEMENT  
 

Component 1: Fiscal and Financial Management 

1. 

Scope of Assistance 

 
1. 
The  introduction  of  a  medium-term  expenditure  framework  (MTEF)  is  a  complex 
undertaking  as  it  entails  a  major  change  in  current  fiscal  management  practices.  Under  this 
component capacity building support will be provided to Finance Department (FD), Planning and 
Development  Department  (P&DD)  and  selected  line  departments,  namely,  Department  of 
Irrigation and Power (DI&P), and Department of Health (DOH). The purpose of this component 
is to create the enabling conditions for the implementation of MTEF by strengthening fiscal and 
financial management practices, including the continuation of work on tax reforms undertaken in 
the Punjab Resource Management Program (PRMP). The component provides support in three 
main  areas:  (i)  improving  public  resource  management,  (ii)  increasing  transparency  and 
accountability  of  the  budget  process,  and  (iii)  achieving  performance  orientation  in  the  annual 
budgeting process. 
 

2. 

Key Activities 

2. 
Subcomponent  1:  Improve  Public  Resource  Management.  This  subcomponent  is 
aimed  at  improving  fiscal  and  financial  management  practices  in  the  FD  and  P&DD  by 
strengthening: (i) reliability of fiscal projections; (ii) preparation, execution, and monitoring of the 
budget  process;  and  (iii)  coordination  between  the  recurrent  and  development  sides  of  the 
budget.  The  subcomponent  also  supports  a  number  of  studies  to  assess  specific  issues 
pertaining  to  the  current  budget  process,  including:  (i)  supplementary  budget  procedure,  and 
(ii) assessment of the Provincial Finance Commission awards. Support will also be provided to 
develop capacity in the medium-term budget framework (MTBF) and medium-term development 
framework (MTDF) cells of FD and P&DD, respectively. 

3. 
Subcomponent  2:  Achieve  Performance  Orientation  in  the  Annual  Budgeting 
Process. This subcomponent is aimed at building capacity in two pilot departments—DOH and 
DI&P—in the areas of fiscal and financial management and medium-term planning. Support for 
DOH focuses on establishing a Strategy and Policy Unit in DOH, and subsequently developing 
standards of services and related costing methodology to assess the financing of medium-term 
requirements.  Support  for  DI&P  will  focus  on  defining  and  costing  service  delivery  standards, 
developing  mechanisms  to  enforce  them,  and  linking  the  costing  methodology  with  the 
budgeting  process.  The  first  round  of  the  citizen  satisfaction  survey  will  be  conducted  in 
selected district governments to assess public opinion on the quality of public service delivery in 
primary and secondary health care and education.

the  Punjab  Government  Efficiency

A. 
 
The  purpose  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  grant  is  to:  (i)  effectively  coordinate  the 
1. 
implementation  of 
Improvement  Program  (PGEIP); 
(ii) support the management committee of the Punjab Pension Fund (PPF) in establishing sound 
fiduciary  systems  and  operational  structure;  (iii)  support  the  Management  and  Professional 
Development  Department  (MPDD)  in  strengthening  the  consultation,  coordination,  and 
interactions  with  provincial  line  departments  and  local  governments  on  civil  servant  capacity- 
building issues; and (iv) assist the effective functioning of the working groups for reviewing the 
rules of business and human resource policies. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
Coordination  Support.  Successful  implementation  of  public  sector  reforms  requires 
effective  coordination  between  different  agencies.  With  multiple  stakeholders  for  each  core 
policy  area  (CPA),  the  TA  will  provide  expertise  to  help  the  executing  agency  (EA)  and  key 
implementing  agencies  (IAs)  in  program  coordination  as  well  as  in  monitoring  and  evaluating 
the progress of both program and TA loan implementation. The TA will recruit one experienced 
national consultant under each CPA, to be based at the program management unit (PMU), who 
will:  (i)  act  as  an  interface  between  the  PMU  and  concerned  IAs  to  ensure  that  the  technical 
aspects of the policy actions and the underlying recruitments are fully understood; (ii) provide 
an  independent  assessment  to  PMU  as  well  as  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  on 
program  implementation;  (iii)  assist  in  identifying  and  addressing  problems,  including  those 
relating to procurement and project implementation arrangements under the TA loan; and (iv) 
provide inputs to PMU and ADB for the formulation of policy actions for subprogram (SP) 2 and 
SP3. 
 
3. 
In  addition,  the  TA  grant  will  support  the  management  committee  of  the  PPF  in 
establishing  sound  fiduciary  systems  and  operational  structure.  The TA  grant  will  also  provide 
an  experienced  local  expert  to  work  as  a  capacity-building  coordinator  for  the  MPDD  of  the 
Punjab.  The  expert  will  assist  the  MPDD  in  carrying  out  widespread  stakeholder  consultation, 
and  help  to  enhance  the  linkage  between  the  MPDD  and  provincial  line  departments.  In 
particular,  the  expert  will  support  the  MPDD  in  strengthening  its  interaction  and  expanding  its 
capacity-building outreach at the local government level, where capacity-building needs remain 
enormous  in  the  post-devolution  era.  Furthermore,  two  working  groups  have  recently  been 
established  to  assist  with  civil  service  policy  review  and  improvement:  one  for  reviewing  the 
rules  of  business  in  Punjab,  and  the  other  for  reviewing  key  human  resource  management 
policies. The TA will support the two working groups to jump-start these important civil service 
reform (CSR) initiatives. Two national consultants will be recruited to provide dedicated support 
to  these  working  groups  in  reviewing  polices,  making  recommendations,  and  implementing 
necessary changes.

Development Goals (MDGs) in health. Program outputs will include (i) a performance-oriented 
health-care  delivery  system,  (ii) sustained  financing  modalities  for  the  health  sector,  and  (iii) 
well-defined  mechanisms  for  private  sector  participation  in  the  provision  of  health  services. 
Additional details are in Appendix 3. 
 
3. 
Component  2:  PAJP.  The objective of the proposed PAJP is to build on the progress 
made  under  the  Pakistan  Access  to  Justice  Program  to  deepen  judicial  reforms  at  the 
provincial  level.  Program  outputs  will  include  (i)  improved  police  functions  through  effective 
social regulations, (ii) institutionalization of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms for local 
disputes,  and  (iii)  strengthening  of  citizen  rights  through  public  awareness  and  legal  literacy. 
Additional details are in Appendix 3. 
 
B. 
 
4. 
The Department of Health will be the Executing Agency (EA) and Implementing Agency 
(IA)  for  component  1.  The  PAJP  will  be  coordinated  by  the  Planning  and  Development 
Department of the government of the Punjab (GoPb).  
 
C.

assistance  (TA)  funding  program  to  cover  the  consultancy  services  and  the  cost  of  training, 
seminars and workshops. The GoPb’s in-kind contribution will be $225,000.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY  
 

A. 

Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis  
 
In 2003, the government of the Punjab (GoPb) introduced the Punjab-Poverty Reduction 
1. 
Strategy Paper (P-PRSP) as its response to the steeply increasing incidence of poverty during 
the 1990s. The P-PRSP identified (i) governance reform, (ii) strengthening of planning capability, 
(iii)  improvements  in  service  delivery,  (iv)  fiscal  and  financial  reforms,  (v) income  and 
employment  generation,  and  (vi)  gender  mainstreaming  as  key  elements  of  effective  poverty 
reduction  in  the  Punjab.  The  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program  (PRMP)  was  aimed  at 
supporting improvements in these areas. PRMP helped develop and operationalize the poverty-
focused investment strategies for six key sectors in order to implement the P-PRSP. It likewise 
supported  revenue  mobilization,  budgeting,  and  debt  management  reforms  to  create  fiscal 
space and improve the use of fiscal resources. This has set the stage for the second-generation 
reforms under the Punjab Government Efficiency Improvement Program (PGEIP), which seeks 
to  strengthen  the  performance  orientation  of  the  budget,  undertake  pension  reform  to  create 
additional fiscal space for social and development expenditures, improve the responsiveness of 
the civil service to public's needs, particularly in the delivery of pro-poor services; and promote 
private sector development for income generation and employment creation. 
 
Likewise,  the  PGEIP  has  strong  linkage  with  both  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
2. 
country  strategy  and  the  national  poverty  reduction  strategy.  ADB’s  Pakistan  country  strategy 
and  program  (CSP)  for  2002–2006, 1  which  was  based  on  ADB’s  poverty  assessment  for 
Pakistan  in  20022 and  developed  in  the  context  of  the  national  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy 
Paper  (PRSP),  emphasized  poor  governance  as  a  key  cause  of  poverty.  The  CSP  update 
2005–2008  further  emphasized  the  importance  of  governance  reforms.  Poor  governance  not 
only resulted in poor public service delivery and greater vulnerability, but also led to a drop in 
business confidence, which in turn resulted in lower investment levels and growth. ADB’s draft 
country partnership strategy (CPS) for 2007–2011 for Pakistan maintains this focus, identifying 
governance and institutional bottlenecks as binding constraints on growth and poverty reduction. 
This  is  consistent  with  the  government’s  draft  second-generation  poverty  reduction  strategy, 
PRSP II, which includes effective governance and management as a key pillar. 
 
B. 

Poverty Analysis: Poverty and Public Resource Management in the Punjab 

3. 
Official  poverty  indicators  for  2004–2005  indicate  a  sharp  improvement  in  the  poverty 
situation for Pakistan. The national poverty head-count ratio, which shows the percentage of the 
population  living  below  the  poverty  line  declining  by  10.6  percentage  points  from  34.46%  in 
2001–2002  to  23.9%  in  2004–2005.  In  absolute  numbers,  the  number  of  poor  persons  in 
Pakistan fell from 49.23 million to 36.45 million. The changes in poverty incidence in Pakistan in 
recent years demonstrate the importance of economic growth in poverty reduction.  
 
4. 
Likewise, the Punjab’s average annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 8% from 
fiscal year (FY) 2003 to FY2007 has contributed to the improvement in the poverty situation in 
the Punjab. In addition, increase in social spending has also improved social conditions. From a 
poverty  head-count  ratio  of  34.1%  in  FY2002,  the  ratio  decreased  by  11  percentage  points  to 
about  23%  in  FY2005.  It  is  estimated  that  the  ratio  has  further  declined  by  another  2.1 
percentage points in FY2007. Gains are similarly seen in some social sectors like education and

health.  The  literacy  rate  improved  from  47%  in  FY2002  to  62%  in  FY2007,  while  net  primary 
enrollment  rate  rose  from  45%  to  70%  during  the  same  period.  Infant  mortality  rate  per  1,000 
live births declined from 82 in FY2002 to 72 in FY2007, while child mortality rate per 1,000 live 
births3 decreased from 119 to 105. The percentage of children between 12 and 23 months that 
have been fully immunized increased from 57% to 76% from FY2002 to FY2007. There has also 
been improvement in maternal health care during the same period, with maternal mortality ratio 
per 100,000 live births dropping from 350 to 257. In spite of these gains, however, the poverty 
level  still  exceeds  20%  and  social  indicators  lag  behind  those  of  comparable  low-income 
countries. For instance, Mongolia and Viet Nam, which have slightly lower per capita incomes4 
than the Punjab,5 have higher net primary enrollment rates, at 82.4% (for Mongolia) and 94.3% 
(for Viet Nam). In terms of health indicators, child and infant mortality rates for these countries 
are at least half of those in the Punjab. Bangladesh, which has a significantly lower per capita 
income6 than  the  Punjab,  has  a  higher  net  primary  enrollment  rate  and  lower  child  and  infant 
mortality  rates.  Thus,  reducing  poverty  and  improving  social  and  living  conditions  remain  key 
tasks for the GoPb.7 
 
The  increase  in  investment  in  the  social  sectors  in  recent  years  is  encouraging.  The 
5. 
World  Bank’s  Punjab  Education  Sector  Reform  Program  focuses  on  pro-poor  initiatives, 
including  the  provision  of  free  textbooks  and  stipends  to  girl  students  as  part  of  efforts  to 
increase  enrollment  and  retention  in  poor  districts.  Interventions  under  the  Decentralization 
Support  Program8 and  the  Punjab  Devolved  Social  Services  Program  (PDSSP)9 are  building 
capacity  at  provincial  and  local  government  levels  for  efficient  and  effective  pro-poor  service 
delivery with better monitoring, evaluation, and gender sensitivity.  
 
PRMP  has  contributed  to  poverty  reduction  in  Punjab.  Subprogram  1  focused  on  the 
6. 
development of poverty-focused investment strategies for key social sectors, and subprogram 2 
pushed for the approval and operationalization of these strategies. Subprogram 1 helped reduce 
the  high  debt  service  burden  through  early  retirement  of  cash  development  loans,  and  initial 
restructuring of provincial taxes has resulted in an increase in revenues. Likewise, subsidies not 
explicitly  targeting  the  poor  were  phased  out.  This  has  created  additional  fiscal  space  to 
accommodate  more  PRSP-related  expenditures.  Subprogram  2  focused  largely  on  improving 
public service delivery and accelerating growth through private sector development. The GoPb 
has implemented the medium-term budget framework (MTBF) and has taken steps to introduce 
timely,  reliable,  and  publicly  accessible  public  accounts.  It  has  also  introduced  measures  to 
support sustained private sector development. The continuity of reforms in underlying systems 
and processes to manage public resources is crucial if the incidence of poverty in Punjab is to 
be further reduced.  
 
7. 
The  PGEIP  envisages  further  improvement  in  the  delivery  of  pro-poor  social  services. 
The  implementation  of  the  medium-term  expenditure  framework  (MTEF)  enhances  the 
performance orientation of the budget, and improves its pro-poor focus. Efforts are also being 
taken to strengthen linkages between the budget and service delivery in key social sectors such

as  health.  The  PGEIP  also  addresses  the  fiscal  squeeze  arising  from  pension  liabilities  by

C. 

Participation Process 

1. 

Stakeholder Analysis  

8. 
The  design  of  the  PGEIP  incorporates  the  results  of  stakeholder  consultations  at  all 
levels  of  government  and  civil  society.  Further,  it  incorporates  lessons  learned  during  the 
consultative process for the preparation and implementation of the two PRMP subprograms, the 
Decentralization Support Program, and the PDSSP.  
 
9. 
The consensus-building strategy for the PGEIP is in line with that used for PRMP, which 
was the result of policy dialogue that began in 2002, with the ADB technical assistance (TA).10 
The  PGEIP  entails  a  continuous  policy  dialogue  until  2010  and  possibly  beyond,  with  all  key 
stakeholders,  including  politicians,  civil  servants,  civil  society  organizations,  the  academic 
community, media, private sector representatives, and other development partners. In addition, 
the  cluster  approach,  with  regular  dialogue,  will  continue  to  ensure  that  the  reforms,  despite 
being demanding, stay broadly on track. 
 
10. 
The PGEIP will continue to support for the Punjab Development Forum (PDF), which is a 
well-established and regular event that brings all stakeholders together to (i) study and evaluate 
development progress in Punjab, (ii) discuss key challenges, and (iii) provide guidance on how 
to address the development challenges.11  
 

2. 

Participation Strategy 

11. 
The  GoPb  has  adopted  a  participatory  approach  in  designing  and  implementing  its 
poverty  reduction  programs,  starting  with  wide-ranging  consultations  with  stakeholders  in  the 
formulation  of  the  P-PRSP.  The  government’s  commitment  to  participation  continues  with  its 
ongoing  reform  effort,  which  emphasizes  consultation  through  initiatives  such  as  the  PDF. 
Under subprograms 1 and 2 of PRMP, consultations were a regular feature, including the MTBF 
Forum  in  October  2004.  The  PGEIP  further  strengthens  the  systems  and  procedures  in  the 
public  sector  to  promote  accessibility,  accountability,  transparency,  and  fiscal  discipline  by 
developing and implementing the MTEF. It also encourages broader participation of the private 
sector in the Punjab’s economic activity and fosters public-private partnerships. As participatory 
approaches  gain  ground  in  government  processes,  it  is  imperative  to  follow  through  with  the 
institutionalization of broader stakeholder participation with the support of the political leadership 
and bureaucracy.  
 
12. 
On the basis of the experience with PRMP and recommendations of evaluation studies 
of  other  policy-based  lending  programs,  the  PGEIP  will  continue  to  convene  the  PDF  and  to 
conduct  other  participatory  processes,  engaging  stakeholders  at  federal,  provincial,  and  local 
levels. During the program preparation, the PGEIP benefited from workshops in the formulation

                                            Appendix 13            97                   

 

 

of  policy  reform  actions  from  key  stakeholders.  It  will  continue  to  provide  the  venue  for 
addressing various  stakeholders’  concerns  related  to  its  reform  program.  The  PGEIP  receives 
oversight and guidance through a high-level steering committee, which includes representatives 
of civil society and the private sector. As the reform process under the PGEIP deepens, the role 
of  the  steering  committee  will  become  central  to  its  success.  More  vigorous  and  regular 
direction from the steering committee will be required under the PGEIP.  
 
D. 

Social Issues 

13. 
The P-PRSP emphasized the need to establish a system for monitoring and evaluating 
social and economic conditions. It identified key indicators, baselines, and targets, and clearly 
defined  the  responsibility  for  the  collection  of  data  related  to  each  indicator.  The  ADB  TA 
projects  Local  Government  Performance  Enhancement 12  and  Gender  and  Governance 
Mainstreaming 13  also  established  baselines  and  targets  for  gender,  access,  equity,  and 
sustainability.  In  addition,  the  TA  project  Enhancing  Capacity  for  Poverty  Reduction  and 
Resource Management in Punjab14 promoted poverty-focused development planning, including 
the  engagement  of  a  monitoring  and  evaluation  specialist,  who  worked  with  the  GoPb  to 
develop  key  performance  indicators  for  monitoring  progress  against  social  sector  targets.  The 
work  on  monitoring  and  evaluation  done  under  the  previous  TA  and  DSSP  is  encouraging. 
Under subprogram 2, the Planning and Development Department (P&DD) has strengthened its 
monitoring  procedures  for  tracking  expenditures  and  outcomes  of  the  annual  development 
program and for implementing poverty-focused investment strategies. The PGEIP complements 
this  by  infusing  greater  transparency,  accountability,  and  performance  orientation  in  public 
expenditures  through  MTEF  and  adopting  service  delivery  standards.  The  GoPb  will  also 
institute mechanisms for tracking expenditure performance under the PGEIP. 
 

1. 

Gender 

Although  education  indicators  generally  improved  from  2001–2002  to  2004–2005, 
14. 
statistics  from  the  2004–2005  Pakistan  Social  and  Living  Standards  Measurement  Survey 
indicate  the  continued  wide  gender  disparities  in  access  to  education  in  the  Punjab.  For 
instance,  the  literacy  rate  for  females  in  the  province  was  21%  lower  than  that  for  males  in 
FY2005.  Large  disparities  likewise  persist  across  the  urban  and  rural  sectors,  and  tend  to  be 
higher in rural areas. There also remains a wide gap in employment opportunities. The 2005–
2006 Labor Force Survey shows the persistence of the low labor force participation rate among 
women in the Punjab, at 17.9% compared with 51.6% for males. 
 
15. 
A preliminary gender review of federal, provincial, and district public sector expenditure 
and  its  management  suggests  a  critical  need  for  cross-sector  and  comprehensive  gender 
analysis,  planning,  budgeting,  auditing,  and  monitoring  systems,  and  a  methodology  and 
mechanisms  to  ensure  gender-balanced  resource  distribution  at  all  three  levels.  Fulfilling 
commitments on mainstreaming gender is one of the key objectives of PRMP. The approval and 
implementation  of  the  provincial  gender  reform  action  plan  (GRAP)  was  achieved  under 
subprogram  1.  A  PRs612  million  GRAP  Planning  Commission  pro-forma  I  (PC-I)  with  the 
objective of mainstreaming gender at all levels of the government was approved by the GoPb.

Appendix 13 

 

Under subprogram 2, the GoPb established the Change Management Unit (CMU), which will be 
responsible for ensuring that gender considerations are taken into account in reform programs. 
Recently  the  CMU  was  upgraded  to  the  Public  Policy  and  Change  Management  Wing 
(PPCMW).  The  PGEIP  will  further  strengthen  change  management  by  introducing  change 
management agents in core departments and district governments. 
 

2. 

Access 

The reforms proposed under the PGEIP are designed to further improve access to social 
16. 
services,  particularly  in  the  health  sector,  by  strengthening  the  linkage  between  the  budget 
process  and  service  delivery.  Implementation  of  MTEF  will  encourage  performance-based 
budgets, which means better public access to services, and will enhance the pro-poor focus of 
public expenditures. An improved civil service will likewise be more responsive to the needs of 
the  general  public,  including  the  poor  and  marginalized  sectors.  It  will  also  result  in  improved 
governance, which will lower transaction costs as rent-seeking behavior and graft are reduced. 
The  resulting  lower  transaction  costs  will  benefit  the  poor  and  the  non-poor  alike,  improving 
access  for  all.  Not  only  will  pension  reforms  result  in  a  well-functioning  pension  system,  it  will 
provide access to much-needed financial security over the long term, as well as fiscal space for 
pro-poor expenditures as the share of pension servicing in the budget declines over time. 
 

3. 

Equity 

17. 
The PGEIP will promote greater equity in the Punjab. Performance orientation and fiscal 
discipline infused by MTEF as well as the adoption of service delivery standards will ensure that 
improved service delivery benefits the poor. Likewise, better and more efficient public resource 
management  will  create  additional  fiscal  space  for  pro-poor  expenditures.  Within  the  public 
service, civil service reforms will incorporate equity considerations through merit-based human 
resources management. 
 

4. 

Sustainability 

18. 
ADB  will  continue  to  support  measures  to  improve  effective  resource  management 
(which  was  identified  as  the  basis  for  poverty  reduction  in  the  P-PRSP).  PRMP  has  already 
helped  bring  about  significant  reforms  in  development  planning  and  resource  management 
systems.  The  PGEIP  will  undertake  the  second-generation  reforms  needed  to  sustain  and 
further improve these efforts. 
 
19. 
Under  the  PRMP,  the  GoPb  started  important  reforms,  including  the  preparation  of 
MTBF  and  MTDF,  tax  reforms,  procurement  reforms,  improvements  in  the  planning  and 
approval  process  for  development  projects,  and  the  approval  of  a  new  industrial  policy  that 
addresses many of the concerns of the private sector. To ensure the sustainability of the reform 
process,  the  PGEIP  reinforces  previous  reforms  with  civil  service  reform  and  performance-
based  budgeting.  Also,  a  strengthened  and  financially  viable  pension  system  will  remove 
pension liabilities from the budget, thereby creating more fiscal space for other social services. 
In  addition,  the  focus  of  the  PGEIP  on  creating  an  environment  conducive  to  private  sector 
activities opens the door to partnerships forged with the private sector to pursue reforms. Finally, 
the  PGEIP  will  continue  to  support  the  GoPb  in  implementing  the  essentially  home-grown 
reform  agenda  that  was  begun  under  PRMP.  The  GoPb’s  strong  sense  of  ownership  of  the 
reform  process  reinforces  the  prospects  for  the  long-term  sustainability  of  the  achievements 
under the PGEIP.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan 
Public  resource  management  deals  with  processes  and  governance  mechanisms  for  mobilization  of  revenue  and 
allocation for development purposes. Effective public resource management will increase revenues, improve allocation 
efficiency of public expenditures toward high socioeconomic returns, enhance sustainability of and access by the poor 
to public services, including for basic social services and infrastructure, and promote private sector development and 
employment  generation.  Governance  reforms,  including  public  resource  management,  are  a  central  element  in  the 
country poverty analysis. Second generation reforms under the PGEIP will strengthen the performance orientation of 
the budget, free up resources for PRSP-related expenditures, and improve the responsiveness of the civil service to 
public’s need, particularly in delivery of pro-poor services. 
 
 
B. 
Punjab’s  GDP  annual  growth  of  8%  from  FY2003  to  FY2007  has  contributed  to  the  improvement  in  the  poverty 
situation in Punjab. In addition, increase social spending  has also improved social conditions. From a poverty head-
count ratio of 34.1% in FY2002, this decreased by 11 percentage points in FY2005. This is estimated to have further 
declined by another 2.1 percentage points in FY2007. Gains are likewise seen in some social sectors like education 
and health. The literacy rate improved from 47% in FY2002 to 62% in FY2007 while net primary enrolment rate rose 
from 45% to 70% during the same period. Infant mortality rate per 1,000 live births declined from 82 in FY2002 to 72 in 
FY2007  while  child  mortality  rate  per  1,000  live  birthsa  decreased  from  119  to  105.  The  percentage  of  children 
between  12  and  23  months  that  have  been  fully  immunized  increased  from  57%  to  76%  from  FY2002  to  FY2007. 
There has likewise been improvement in maternal health care during the same period with maternal mortality ratio per 
100,000  live  births  dropping  from  350  to  257.  In  spite  of  these  gains,  poverty  level  still  exceeds  20%  and  social 
indicators lag behind that of other comparable low income countries. Thus, reducing poverty and improving social and 
living conditions remain key tasks for the GoPb.b 
 
PRMP is a central element of the Punjab PRSP to reduce the incidence of poverty in Punjab. Subprogram 1 focused 
on the development of poverty-focused investment strategies for key social sectors, and Subprogram 2 pushed for the 
approval  and  operationalization  of  these  strategies.  Subprogram  1  helped  to  reduce  the  high  debt  service  burden 
through  early  retirement  of  cash  development  loans  and  initial  restructuring  of  provincial  taxes  has  resulted  in  an 
increase in revenues. Likewise, subsidies not explicitly targeting the poor were phased out. This has created additional 
fiscal  space  to  accommodate  more  PRSP-related  expenditures.  Subprogram  2  focused  largely  on  improving  public 
service delivery and accelerating growth through private sector development. The GoPb has implemented the MTBF 
and  introduced  timely,  reliable  and  publicly  accessible  public  accounts.  It  has  also  introduced  measures  to  support 
sustained  private  sector  development.  The  continuity  of  reforms  in  underlying  systems  and  processes  to  manage 
public resources is crucial if the incidence of poverty in Punjab is to be further reduced.  
 
The PGEIP continues to support the three components of the ADB’s poverty reduction strategy: pro-poor sustainable 
economic  growth,  good  governance,  and  social  development.  The  PGEIP  envisages  the  further  improvement  in  the 
delivery  of  pro-poor  social  services.  The  implementation  of  the  MTEF  enhances  the  performance  orientation  of  the 
budget, and improves its pro-poor focus. Efforts are also taken to strengthen linkages between the budget and service 
delivery  in  key  social  sectors  such  as  health.  The  PGEIP  also  addresses  the  fiscal  squeeze  arising  from  pension 
liabilities by making them off-budget and creating viable pension and general provident funds. This creates additional 
fiscal  space  for  pro-poor  expenditures.  Civil  service  reform  is  pursued  to  improve  the  responsiveness  of  the  latter 
towards the needs of the public. Lastly, encouraging public-private partnerships expands the resources available for 
pro-poor services in Punjab.
